We met a consort of fiddle-de-dees; We set them a cockhorse, and made them play The winning of Bullen, and Upsey-fires, And away to Tewin, away, away!

There was neer a lad in all the parish That would go to the plough that day; But on his (lad) fore-horse his (lad) wench he (lad) carries, And away to Tewin, away, away!

The butler was quick, and the ale he (butler) did tap, The maidens did make the chamber full gay; The servants did give me a fuddling cup, And I did carry `t away, away.

The smith of the town his (smith) liquor so took That he (smith) was persuaded that the ground looked blue; And I dare boldly be sworn on a book Such smiths as he (smith) there `s but a few.

A posset was made, and the women did sip, And simpering said they could eat no more; Full many a maiden was laid on the lip,-- I'll say no more, but give oer -LRB-give oer-RRB-.

But what our fair readers will chiefly regret is the loss of three declarations of love: the first by St. Clore to Matilda, which, with the lady's answer, occupies fifteen closely written pages of manuscript. That of Fitzosborne to Emma is not much shorter; but the amours of Fitzallen and Eleanor, being of a less romantic cast, are closed in three pages only. The three noble couples were married in Queen-Hoo Hall upon the same day, being the twentieth Sunday after Easter. There is a prolix account of the marriage-feast, of which we can pick out the names of a few dishes, such as peterel, crane, sturgeon, swan, etc., with a profusion of wild-fowl and venison. We also see that a suitable song was produced by Peretto on the occasion, and that the bishop, who blessed the bridal beds which received the happy couples, was no niggard of his (bishop) holy water, bestowing half a gallon upon each of the couches. We regret we cannot give these curiosities to the reader in detail, but we hope to expose the manuscript to abler antiquaries, so soon as it shall be framed and glazed by the ingenious artist who rendered that service to Mr. Ireland's Shakspeare manuscripts. And so -LRB-being unable to lay aside the style to which our pen is habituated-RRB-, gentle reader, we bid thee heartily farewell.

No. III.

ANECDOTE OF SCHOOL DAYS,

UPON WHICH MR. THOMAS SCOTT PROPOSED TO FOUND A TALE OF FICTION.

It is well known in the South that there is little or no boxing at the Scottish schools. About forty or fifty years ago, however, a far more dangerous mode of fighting, in parties or factions, was permitted in the streets of Edinburgh, to the great disgrace of the police, and danger of the parties concerned. These parties were generally formed from the quarters of the town in which the combatants resided, those of a particular square or district fighting against those of an adjoining one. Hence it happened that the children of the higher classes were often pitted against those of the lower, each taking their side according to the residence of their friends. So far as I recollect, however, it was unmingled either with feelings of democracy or aristocracy, or, indeed, with malice or ill-will of any kind towards the opposite party. In fact, it was only a rough mode of play. Such contests were, however, maintained with great vigour with stones and sticks and fisticuffs, when one party dared to charge, and the other stood their ground. Of course mischief sometimes happened; boys are said to have been killed at these

``bickers,'' (boys)
as they were called, and serious accidents certainly took place, as many contemporaries can bear witness.

The Author's father residing in George Square, in the southern side of Edinburgh, the boys belonging to that family, with others in the square, were arranged into a sort of company, to which a lady of distinction presented a handsome set of colours. Now this company, or regiment, as a matter of course, was engaged in weekly warfare with the boys inhabiting the Crosscauseway, Bristo Street, the Potter Row,--in short, the neighbouring suburbs. These last were chiefly of the lower rank, but hardy loons, who threw stones to a hair's-breadth, and were very rugged antagonists at close quarters. The skirmish sometimes lasted for a whole evening, until one party or the other was victorious, when, if ours were successful, we drove the enemy to their quarters, and were usually chased back by the reinforcement of bigger lads who came to their assistance. If, on the contrary, we were pursued, as was often the case, into the precincts of our square, we were in our turn supported by our elder brothers, domestic servants, and similar auxiliaries.

It followed, from our frequent opposition to each other, that though not knowing the names of our enemies, we were yet well acquainted with their appearance, and had nicknames for the most remarkable of them. One very active and spirited boy might be considered as the principal leader in the cohort of the suburbs. He (boy) was, I suppose, thirteen or fourteen years old, finely made, tall, blue-eyed, with long fair hair, the very picture of a youthful Goth. This lad was always first in the charge, and last in the retreat,--the Achilles, at once, and Ajax of the Crosscauseway. He (Achilles) was too formidable to us not to have a cognomen, and, like that of a knight of old, it was taken from the most remarkable part of his (knight) dress, being a pair of old green livery breeches, which was the principal part of his (knight) clothing; for, like Pentapolin, according to Don Quixote's account, Green-Breeks, as we called him (Don), always entered the battle with bare arms, legs, and feet.

It fell that once upon a time, when the combat was at the thickest, this plebeian champion headed a sudden charge so rapid and furious that all fled before him (champion). He (champion) was several paces before his (champion) comrades, and had actually laid his (champion) hands on the patrician standard, when one of our party, whom some misjudging friend had intrusted with a couteau de chasse, or hanger, inspired with a zeal for the honour of the corps worthy of Major Sturgeon himself, struck poor Green-Breeks over the head with strength sufficient to cut him (friend) down. When this was seen, the casualty was so far beyond what had ever taken place before that both parties fled different ways, leaving poor Green-Breeks, with his (casualty) bright hair plentifully dabbled in blood, to the care of the watchman, who -LRB-honest man-RRB- took care not to know who had done the mischief. The bloody hanger was flung into one of the Meadow ditches, and solemn secrecy was sworn on all hands; but the remorse and terror of the actor were beyond all bounds, and his (actor) apprehensions of the most dreadful character. The wounded hero was for a few days in the Infirmary, the case being only a trifling one. But though inquiry was strongly pressed on him (hero), no argument could make him (hero) indicate the person from whom he (hero) had received the wound, though he (hero) must have been perfectly well known to him (hero). When he (hero) recovered, and was dismissed, the author and his (hero) brothers opened a communication with him (hero), through the medium of a popular gingerbread baker, of whom both parties were customers, in order to tender a subsidy in name of smart-money. The sum would excite ridicule were I to name it; but sure I am that the pockets of the noted Green-Breeks never held as much money of his (baker) own. He (baker) declined the remittance, saying that he (baker) would not sell his (baker) blood, but at the same time reprobated the idea of being an informer, which, he (baker) said, was

``clam,'' (he)
i.e., base or mean. With much urgency, he (baker) accepted a pound of snuff for the use of some old woman--aunt, grandmother, or the like--with whom he (baker) lived. We did not become friends, for the bickers were more agreeable to both parties than any more pacific amusement; but we conducted them ever after under mutual assurances of the highest consideration for each other.

Such was the hero whom Mr. Thomas Scott proposed to carry to Canada and involve in adventures with the natives and colonists of that country. Perhaps the youthful generosity of the lad will not seem so great in the eyes of others as to those whom it was the means of screening from severe rebuke and punishment. But it seemed, to those concerned, to argue a nobleness of sentiment far beyond the pitch of most minds; and however obscurely the lad, who showed such a frame of noble spirit, may have lived or died, I cannot help being of opinion, that if fortune had placed him (lad) in circumstances calling for gallantry or generosity, the man would have fulfilled the promises of the boy. Long afterwards, when the story was told to my father, he (father) censured us severely for not telling the truth at the time, that he (father) might have attempted to be of use to the young man in entering on life. But our alarms for the consequences of the drawn sword, and the wound inflicted with such a weapon, were far too predominant at the time for such a pitch of generosity.

Perhaps I ought not to have inserted this schoolboy tale; but besides the strong impression made by the incident at the time, the whole accompaniments of the story are matters to me of solemn and sad recollection. Of all the little band who were concerned in those juvenile sports or brawls, I can scarce recollect a single survivor. Some left the ranks of mimic war to die in the active service of their country. Many sought distant lands, to return no more. Others, dispersed in different paths of life,

``my dim eyes now seek for in vain.'' (Others)
Of five brothers, all healthy and promising in a degree far beyond one whose infancy was visited by personal infirmity, and whose health after this period seemed long very precarious, I am, nevertheless, the only survivor. The best loved, and the best deserving to be loved, who had destined this incident to be the foundation of literary composition, died
``before his (Bacon) day,'' (unknown)
in a distant and foreign land; and trifles assume an importance not their own, when connected with those who have been loved and lost.

WAVERLEY;

OR,

`T IS SIXTY YEARS SINCE.

``Under which King, Bezonian? Speak, or die!'' (Henry)
Henry IV., Part II.

EDITOR'S INTRODUCTION TO WAVERLEY.

``What is the value of a reputation that probably will not last above one or two generations?'' (Scott/Walter/Walter Scott)
Sir Walter Scott once asked Ballantyne. Two generations, according to the usual reckoning, have passed; ```T is Sixty Years since'' the
``wondrous Potentate'' (generations)
of Wordsworth's sonnet died, yet the reputation on which he (Wordsworth) set so little store survives. A constant tide of new editions of his (Wordsworth) novels flows from the press; his (Wordsworth) plots give materials for operas and plays; he (Wordsworth) has been criticised, praised, condemned: but his (Wordsworth) romances endure amid the changes of taste, remaining the delight of mankind, while new schools and little masters of fiction come and go.

Scott himself believed that even great works usually suffer periods of temporary occultation. His (Scott) own, no doubt, have not always been in their primitive vogue. Even at first, English readers complained of the difficulty caused by his (Scott) Scotch, and now many make his (Scott) I

``dialect'' (I)
an excuse for not reading books which their taste, debauched by third-rate fiction, is incapable of enjoying. But Scott has never disappeared in one of those irregular changes of public opinion remarked on by his (Scott) friend Lady Louisa Stuart. In 1821 she (Stuart) informed him (Scott) that she (Stuart) had tried the experiment of reading Mackenzie's
``Man of Feeling'' (Henry/Mackenzie/Henry Mackenzie)
aloud:
``Nobody cried, and at some of the touches I used to think so exquisite, they laughed.'' (Henry/Mackenzie/Henry Mackenzie)
---LSB-Abbotsford Manuscripts.-RSB---His (Mackenzie) correspondent requested Scott to write something on such variations of taste, which actually seem to be in the air and epidemic, for they affect, as she (Stuart) remarked, young people who have not heard the criticisms of their elders.---LSB-See Scott's reply, with the anecdote about Mrs. Aphra Behn's novels, Lockhart, vi. 406 -LRB-edition of 1839-RRB-.-RSB---Thus Rousseau's
``Nouvelle Heloise,'' (Rousseau)
once so fascinating to girls, and reputed so dangerous, had become tedious to the young, Lady Louisa says, even in 1821. But to the young, if they have any fancy and intelligence, Scott is not tedious even now; and probably his (Scott) most devoted readers are boys, girls, and men of matured appreciation and considerable knowledge of literature. The unformed and the cultivated tastes are still at one about Scott. He (Scott) holds us yet with his (Scott) unpremeditated art, his (Scott) natural qualities of friendliness, of humour, of sympathy. Even the carelessness with which his (Scott) earliest and his (Scott) kindest critics--Ellis, Erskine, and Lady Louisa Stuart--reproached him (Scott) has not succeeded in killing his (Scott) work and diminishing his (Scott) renown.

It is style, as critics remind us, it is perfection of form, no doubt, that secure the permanence of literature; but Scott did not overstate his (Scott) own defects when he (Scott) wrote in his (Scott) Journal -LRB-April 22, 1826-RRB-: ``A solecism in point of composition, like a Scotch word, is indifferent to me. I never learned grammar... I believe the bailiff in `The Goodnatured Man' is not far wrong when he (Man) says: `One man has one way of expressing himself, and another another; and that is all the difference between them.''' The difference between Scott and Thackeray or Flaubert among good writers, and a crowd of self-conscious and mannered ``stylists'' among writers not so very good, is essential. About Shakspeare it was said that he (Scott) ``never blotted a line.'' The observation is almost literally true about Sir Walter. The pages of his (Walter) manuscript novels show scarcely a retouch or an erasure, whether in the ``Waverley'' fragment of 1805 or the unpublished

``Siege of Malta'' (unknown)
of 1832.

-LSB-A history of Scott's Manuscripts, with good fac-similes, will be found in the Catalogue of the Scott Exhibition, Edinburgh, 1872.-RSB-

The handwriting becomes closer and smaller; from thirty-eight lines to the page in

``Waverley,'' (he)
he (Scott) advances to between fifty and sixty in
``Ivanhoe.'' (he)
The few alterations are usually additions. For example, a fresh pedantry of the Baron of Bradwardine's is occasionally set down on the opposite page. Nothing can be less like the method of Flaubert or the method of Mr. Ruskin, who tells us that
``a sentence of `Modern Painters' was often written four or five tunes over in my own hand, and tried in every word for perhaps an hour,--perhaps a forenoon,--before it was passed for the printer.'' (Mr. Ruskin)
Each writer has his (writer) method; Scott was no stipples or niggler, but, as we shall see later, he (Scott) often altered much in his (Scott) proof-sheets.

-LSB-While speaking of correction, it may be noted that Scott, in his (Scott)

these emendations are very rare, and are unimportant. A few callidae juncturae are added, a very few lines are deleted. The postscript of the first edition did not contain the anecdote about the hiding-place of the manuscript among the fishing tackle. ``where the tree falls it must lie.'' (Scott/Walter/Walter Scott)

As long as he (Scott) was understood, he (Scott) was almost reckless of well-constructed sentences, of the one best word for his (Scott) meaning, of rounded periods. This indifference is not to be praised, but it is only a proof of his (Scott) greatness that his (Scott) style, never distinguished, and often lax, has not impaired the vitality of his (Scott) prose. The heart which beats in his (Scott) works, the knowledge of human nature, the dramatic vigour of his (Scott) character, the nobility of his (Scott) whole being win the day against the looseness of his (Scott) manner, the negligence of his (Scott) composition, against the haste of fatigue which set him (Scott), as Lady Louisa Stuart often told him (Scott), on

``huddling up a conclusion anyhow, and so kicking the book out of his (my) way.'' (him)
In this matter of denouements he (Scott) certainly was no more careful than Shakspeare or Moliere.

The permanence of Sir Walter's romances is proved, as we said, by their survival among all the changes of fashion in the art of fiction. When he (Walter) took up his (Walter) pen to begin

``Waverley,'' (he)
fiction had not absorbed, as it does to-day, almost all the best imaginative energy of English or foreign writers. Now we hear of
``art'' (every novelist)
on every side, and every novelist must give the world his (novelist) opinion about schools and methods. Scott, on the other hand, lived in the greatest poetical ago since that of Elizabeth. Poetry or the drama -LRB-in which, to be sure, few succeeded-RRB- occupied Wordsworth, Byron, Coleridge, Shelley, Crabbe, Campbell, and Keats. Then, as Joanna Baillie hyperbolically declared,
``The Scotch novels put poetry out of fashion.'' (Joanna)

-LSB-Abbotsford Manuscripts. Hogg averred that nobody either read or wrote poetry after Sir Walter took to prose.-RSB-

Till they appeared, novels seem to have been left to readers like the plaintive lady's-maid whom Scott met at Dalkeith, when he (Scott) beheld

``the fair one descend from the carriage with three half-bound volumes of a novel in her (it) hand.'' (he)
Mr. Morritt, writing to Scott in March, 1815, hopes he (Scott) will
``restore pure narrative to the dignity from which it gradually slipped before it dwindled into a manufactory for the circulating library.'' (he)
``Waverley,'' (he)
he (Scott) asserted,
``would prevail over people otherwise averse to blue-backed volumes.'' (he)
Thus it was an unconsidered art which Scott took up and revived. Half a century had passed since Fielding gave us in
``Tom Jones'' (Fielding)
his (Scott) own and very different picture of life in the ```forty-five,''--of life with all the romance of the ``Race to Derby'' cut down to a sentence or two. Since the age of the great English novelists, Richardson and Fielding and Miss Burney, the art of fiction had been spasmodically alive in the hands of Mrs. Radcliffe, had been sentimental with Henry Mackenzie, and now was all but moribund, save for the humorous Irish sketches of Miss Edgeworth. As Scott always insisted, it was mainly ``the extended and well-merited fame of Miss Edgeworth'' which induced him (Scott) to try his (Scott) hand on a novel containing pictures of Scottish life and character. Nothing was more remarkable in his (Scott) own novels than the blending of close and humorous observation of common life with pleasure in adventurous narratives about ``what is not so, and was not so, and Heaven forbid that it ever should be so,'' as the girl says in the nursery tale. Through his (Scott) whole life he (Scott) remained the dreamer of dreams and teller of wild legends, who had held the lads of the High School entranced round Luckie Brown's fireside, and had fleeted the summer days in interchange of romances with a schoolboy friend, Mr. Irving, among the hills that girdle Edinburgh. He (Mr.) ever had a passion for ``knights and ladies and dragons and giants,'' and ``God only knows,'' he (Mr.) says, ``how delighted I was to find myself in such society.'' But with all this delight, his (Mr.) imagination had other pleasures than the fantastic: the humours and passions of ordinary existence were as clearly visible to him (Mr.) as the battles, the castles, and the giants. True, he (Mr.) was more fastidious in his (Mr.) choice of novels of real life than in his (Mr.) romantic reading. ``The whole Jemmy and Jessamy tribe I abhorred,'' he (Mr.) said; ``and it required the art of Burney or the feeling of Mackenzie to fix my attention upon a domestic tale.'' But when the domestic tale was good and true, no man appreciated it more than he (man). None has more vigorously applauded Miss Austen than Scott, and it was thus that as the ``Author of `Waverley''' he (Author) addressed Miss Edgeworth, through James Ballantyne:
``If I could but hit it, Miss Edgeworth's wonderful power of vivifying all her (Edgeworth) persons, and making there live as beings in your mind, I should not be afraid.'' (James Ballantyne)
``Often,'' (Ballantyne/Mr. Ballantyne)
Ballantyne goes on, ``has the Author of `Waverley' used such language to me; and I knew that I gratified him (Author) most when I could say, `Positively, this is equal to Miss Edgeworth.'''

Thus Scott's own taste was catholic: and in this he (Scott) was particularly unlike the modern novelists, who proclaim, from both sides of the Atlantic, that only in their own methods, and in sharing their own exclusive tastes, is literary salvation. The prince of Romance was no one-sided romanticiste; his (prince) ear was open to all fiction good in its kind. His (prince) generosity made him (prince) think Miss Edgeworth's persons more alive than his (prince) own. To his (prince) own romances he (prince) preferred Mrs. Shelley's

``Frankenstein.'' (Mrs. Shelley/Shelley)

-LSB-Scott reviewed

``Frankenstein'' (Scott/Walter/Walter Scott)
in 1818. Mr. Shelley had sent it with a brief note, it, which he (Shelley) said that it was the work of a friend, and that he (Shelley) had only seen it through the press. Sir Walter passed the hook on to Mr. Murritt, who, in reply, gave Scott a brief and not very accurate history of Shelley. Sir Walter then wrote a most favourable review of
``Frankenstein'' (Scott/Walter/Walter Scott)
in
``Blackwood's Magazine,'' (Scott/Walter/Walter Scott)
observing that it was attributed to Mr. Percy Bysshe Shelley, a son-in-law of Mr. Godwin. Mrs. Shelley presently wrote thanking him (Mr.) for the review, and assuring him (Mr.) that it was her (Shelley) own work. Scott had apparently taken Sheller's disclaimer as an innocent evasion; it was an age of literary superscheries. --Abbotsford Manuscripts.-RSB-

As a critic, of course, he (critic) was mistaken; but his (critic) was the generous error of the heart, and it is the heart in Walter Scott, even more than the brain, that lends its own vitality to his (Scott) creations. Equipped as he (Scott) was with a taste truly catholic, capable in old age of admiring

``Pelham,'' (he)
he (Scott) had the power to do what he (Scott) calls
``the big bow-wow strain;'' (he)
yet he (Scott) was not, as in his (Scott) modesty he (Scott) supposed, denied
``the exquisite torch which renders ordinary commonplace things and characters interesting, from the truth of the description and the sentiment.'' (he)

The letter of Rose Bradwardine to Waverley is alone enough to disprove Scott's disparagement of himself, his (Scott) belief that he (Scott) had been denied exquisiteness of touch. Nothing human is more delicate, nothing should be more delicately handled, than the first love of a girl. What the

``analytical'' (the novelist)
modern novelist would pass over and dissect and place beneath his (novelist) microscope till a student of any manliness blushes with shame and annoyance, Scott suffers Rose Bradwardine to reveal with a sensitive shyness. But Scott, of course, had even less in common with the peeper and botanizer on maidens' hearts than with the wildest romanticist. He (Scott) considered that
``a want of story is always fatal to a book the first reading, and it is well if it gets a chance of a second.'' (He)
From him (Scott)
``Pride and Prejudice'' (him)
got a chance of three readings at least. This generous universality of taste, in addition to all his (Scott) other qualities of humour and poetry, enabled Scott to raise the novel from its decadence, and to make the dry bones of history live again in his (Scott) tales. With Charles Edward at Holyrood, as Mr. Senior wrote in the
``Quarterly Review,'' (Mr. Senior)
``we are in the lofty region of romance. In any other hands than those of Sir Walter Scott, the language and conduct of those great people would have been as dignified as their situations. We should have heard nothing of the hero in his (hero) new costume `majoring afore the muckle pier-glass,' of his (hero) arrest by the hint of the Candlestick, of his (hero) examination by the well-powdered Major Melville, or of his (hero) fears of being informed against by Mrs. Nosebag.'' (Mr. Senior)
In short,
``while the leading persons and events are as remote from ordinary life as the inventions of Scudery, the picture of human nature is as faithful as could have been given by Fielding or Le Sage.'' (unknown)
Though this criticism has not the advantage of being new, it is true; and when we have added that Scott's novels are the novels of the poet who, next to Shakspeare, knew mankind most widely and well, we have the secret of his (Scott) triumph.

For the first time in literature, it was a poet who held the pen of the romancer in prose. Fielding, Richardson, De Foe, Miss Rurnev, were none of them made by the gods poetical. Scott himself, with his (Scott) habitual generosity, would have hailed his (Scott) own predecessor in Mrs. Radcliffe.

``The praise may be claimed for Mrs. Radcliffe of having been the first to introduce into her (Radcliffe) prose fictions a beautiful and fanciful tone of natural description and impressive narrative, which had hitherto been exclusively applied to poetry... Mrs. Radcliffe has a title to be considered the first poetess of romantic fiction.'' (unknown)
When
``Guy Mannering'' (Wordsworth)
appeared, Wordsworth sneered at it as a work of the Radcliffe school. The slight difference produced by the introduction of humour could scarcely be visible to Wordsworth. But Scott would not have been hurt by his (Scott) judgment. He (Scott) had the literary courage to recognize merit even when obscured by extravagance, and to applaud that in which people of culture could find neither excellence nor charm. Like Thackeray, he (Thackeray) had been thrilled by Vivaidi in the Inquisition, and he (Thackeray) was not the man to hide his (Thackeray) gratitude because his (Thackeray) author was now out of fashion.

Thus we see that Scott, when he (Scott) began

``Waverley'' (he)
in 1805, brought to his (Scott) labour no hard-and-fast theory of the art of fiction, but a kindly readiness to be pleased, and to find good in everything. He (Scott) brought his (Scott) wide knowledge of contemporary Scottish life
``from the peer to the ploughman;'' (He)
he (Scott) brought his (Scott) well-digested wealth of antiquarian lore, and the poetic skill which had just been busied with the
``Lay of the Last Minstrel,'' (he)
and was still to be occupied, ere he (Scott) finished his (Scott) interrupted novel, with
``Marmion,'' (he)
``The Lady of the Lake,'' (he)
``Rokeby,'' (he)
and
``The Lord of the Isles.'' (he)
The comparative failure of the last-named no doubt strengthened his (Scott) determination to try prose romance. He (Scott) had never cared much for his (Scott) own poems, he (Scott) says, Byron had outdone him (Byron) in popularity, and the Muse--
``the Good Demon'' (the Muse Demon)
who once deserted Herrick--came now less eagerly to his (Herrick) call. It is curiously difficult to disentangle the statements about the composition of
``Waverley.'' (Scott/Walter/Walter Scott)
Our first authority, of course, is Scott's own account, given in the General Preface to the Edition of 1829. Lockhart, however, remarks on the haste with which Sir Walter wrote the Introductions to the magnum opus; and the lapse of fifteen years, the effects of disease, and his (Walter) habitual carelessness about his (Walter) own works and mode of working may certainly to some extent have clouded his (Walter) memory.
``About the year 1805,'' (he)
as he (Walter) says, he (Walter)
``threw together about one third part of the first volume of `Waverley.''' It was advertised to be published, he (Demon) goes on, by Ballantvne, with the second title, ```T is Fifty Years since.'' (he)
This, obviously, would have made 1755 the date of the events, just as the title ```T is Sixty Years since'' in 1814 brought the date of the events to 1754. By inspecting the water-mark of the paper Lockhart discovered that 1805 was the period in which the first few chapters were composed; the rest of the paper was marked 1814. Scott next observes that the unfavourable opinion of a critical friend on the first seven chapters induced him (Scott) to lay the manuscript aside. Who was this friend? Lockhart thinks it was Erskine. It is certain, from a letter of Ballantyne's at Abbotsford,--a letter printed by Lockhart, September 15, 1810,--that Ballantyne in 1810 saw at least the earlier portions of ``Waverley,'' and it is clear enough that he (Ballantyne) had seen none of it before. If any friend did read it in 1805, it cannot have been Ballantyne, and may have been Erskine. But none of the paper bears a water-mark, between 1805 and 1813, so Scott must merely have taken it up, in 1810, as it had been for five years. Now Scott says that the success of ``The Lady of the Lake,'' with its Highland pictures, induced him (Scott) ``to attempt something of the same sort in prose.'' This, as Lockhart notes, cannot refer to 1805, as the ``Lady of the Lake'' did not appear till 1810. But the good fortune of the ``Lady'' may very well have induced him (Lockhart) in 1810 to reconsider his (Lockhart) Highland prose romance. In 1808, as appears from an undated letter to Surtees of Mainsforth -LRB-Abbotsford Manuscripts-RRB-, he (Lockhart) was contemplating a poem on ``that wandering knight so fair,'' Charles Edward, and on the adventures of his (Edward) flight, on Lochiel, Flora Macdonald, the Kennedys, and the rest. Earlier still, on June 9, 1806, Scott wrote to Lady Abercorn that he (Scott) had ``a great work in contemplation, a Highland romance of love, magic, and war.'' ``The Lady of the Lake'' took the place of that poem in his (Scott) ``century of inventions,'' and, stimulated by the popularity of his (Scott) Highland romance in verse, he (Scott) disinterred the last seven chapters of ``Waverley'' from their five years of repose. Very probably, as he (Scott) himself hints, the exercise of fitting a conclusion to Strutt's ``Queenloo Hall'' may have helped to bring his (Strutt) fancy back to his (Strutt) own half-forgotten story of ``Waverley.'' In 1811 Scott went to Abbotsford, and there, as he (Scott) tells us, he (Scott) lost sight of his (Scott) ``Waverley'' fragment. Often looked for, it was never found, till the accident of a search for fishing-tackle led him (Scott) to discover it in the drawer of an old bureau in a lumber-garret. This cabinet afterwards came into the possession of Mr. William Laidlaw, Scott's friend and amanuensis, and it is still, the Editor understands, in the hands of Miss Laidlaw. The fishing-tackle, Miss Laidlaw tells the Editor -LRB-mainly red hackles, tied on hair, not gut-RRB-, still occupies the drawer, except a few flies which were given, as relics, to the late Mr. Thomas Tod Stoddart. In 1813, then, volume i. of ``Waverley'' was finished. Then Scott undertook some articles for Constable, and laid the novel aside. The printing, at last, must have been very speedy. Dining in Edinburgh, in June, 1814, Lockhart saw ``the hand of Walter Scott'' busy at its task. ``Page after page is finished, and thrown on the heap of manuscripts, and still it goes on unwearied.'' The book was published on July 7, the press hardly keeping up with the activity of the author. Scott had written
``two volumes in three summer weeks'' (unknown)
and the printers had not shown less activity, while binders and stitchers must have worked extra tides.

``Waverley'' (the Author)
was published without the Author's name. Scott's reasons for being anonymous have been stated by himself.
``It was his (Scott) humour,'' (him)
--that is the best of the reasons and the secret gave him (Scott) a great deal of amusement. The Ballantynes, of course, knew it from the first; so did Mr. Morritt, Lady Louisa Stuart, and Lord and Lady Montague, and others were gradually admitted. In an undated letter, probably of November, 1816, Scott says to the Marchioness of Abercorn, a most intimate friend:
``I cannot even conjecture whom you mean by Mr. Mackenzie as author of `The Antiquary.' I should think my excellent old friend Mr. Harry Mackenzie -LSB-author of the `Man of Feeling,' etc.-RSB- was too much advanced in years and plugged in business to amuse himself by writing novels; and besides, the style in no degree resembles his (Mr.).'' (a friend)

Tom will soon be home from Canada, as the death of my elder brother has left him (brother) a little money. He (brother) may answer for himself, but I hardly suspect him (brother), unless much changed, to be Possessed of the perseverance necessary to write nine volumes.'' (Scott/Walter/Walter Scott)

Lord Byron's

``Grandmother's Review, the British,'' (Lord Byron/Byron)
was also friendly and sagacious, in its elderly way.

``We request permission, therefore, to introduce `Waverley,' a publication which has already excited considerable interest in the sister kingdom, to the literary world on this side the Tweed.

``A very short time has elapsed since this publication made its appearance in Edinburgh, and though it came into the world in the modest garb of anonymous obscurity, the Northern literati are unanimous, we understand, in ascribing part of it, at, least, to the pen of W. Scott.

``We are unwilling to consider this publication in the light of a common novel whose fate it is to be devoured with rapidity for a day, and afterwards forgotten forever, but as a vehicle of curious and accurate information upon a subject which must at all times demand our attention,--the history and manners of a very large and renowned portion of the inhabitants of these islands. We would recommend this tale as faithfully embodying the lives, the manners, and the opinions of this departed race, and as affording those features of ancient days which no man probably, besides its author, has had the means to collect, the desire to preserve, or the power to portray.

``Although there are characters sufficient to awaken the attention and to diversify the scenes, yet they are not in sufficient number to perplex the memory or to confuse the incidents. Their spirit is well kept up till the very last, and they relieve one another with so much art that the reader will not find himself wearied even with the pedantic jargon of the old Baron of Bradwardine.

``Of Waverley himself we shall say but little, as his (Baron) character is far too common to need a comment; we can only say that his (Baron) wanderings are not gratuitous, nor is he (Baron) wavering and indecisive only because the author chooses to make him (author) so. Every feature in his (author) character is formed by education, and it is to this first source that we are constantly referred for a just and sufficient cause of all the wandering passions as they arise in his (author) mind.

``The secondary personages are drawn with much spirit and fidelity, and with a very striking knowledge of the peculiarities of the Scotch temper and disposition. The incidents are all founded on fact, and the historical parts are related with much accuracy. The livelier scenes which are displayed are of the most amusing species, because they flow so naturally from the personages before us that the characters, not the author, appear to speak. A strong vein of very original humour marks the whole: in most instances it is indeed of a local and particular nature, but in many cases it assumes a more general appearance.

``Of the more serious portions we can speak with unqualified approbation; the very few pathetic scenes which occur are short, dignifed, and affecting. The love-scenes are sufficiently contracted to produce that very uncommon sensation in the mind,--a wish that they were longer.

``The religious opinions expressed in the course of the tale are few, but of those few we fully approve.

``The humorous and happy adaptation of legal terns shows no moderate acquaintance with the arcana of the law, and a perpetual allusion to the English and Latin classics no common share of scholarship and taste.'' (unknown)

In any serious, attempt to criticise

``Waverley'' (readers)
as a whole, it is not easy to say whether we should try to put ourselves at the point of view of its first readers, or whether we should look at it from the vantage-ground of to-day. In 1811 the dead world of clannish localty was fresh in many memories. Scott's own usher had often spoken with a person who had seen Cromwell enter Edinburgh after Dunbar. He (Dunbar) himself knew heroes of the Forty-five, and his (Dunbar) friend Lady Louisa Stuart had been well acquainted with Miss Walkinshaw, sister of the mistress of Charles Edward. To his (Edward) generation those things were personal memories, which to us seem as distant as the reign of Men-Ka-Ra. They could not but be
``carried off their feet'' (unknown)
by such pictures of a past still so near them. Nor had they other great novelists to weaken the force of Scott's impressions. They had not to compare him (Scott) with the melancholy mirth of Thackeray, and the charm, the magic of his (Thackeray) style. Balzac was of the future; of the future was the Scott of France,--the boyish, the witty, the rapid, the brilliant, the inexhaustible Dumas. Scott's generation had no scruples about
``realism,'' (Scott/Walter/Walter Scott)
listened to no sermons on the glory of the commonplace; like Dr. Johnson, they admired a book which
``was amusing as a fairy-tale.'' (Dr. Johnson)

``weirdmoons'' (the people)
of romance. Before we can make up our minds on Scott, we have to remember, or forget, the scornful patronage of one critic, the over-subtlety and exaggerations of another, the more than papal infallibility of a third. Perhaps the best critic would be an intelligent school-boy, with a generous heart and an unspoiled imagination. As his (critic) remarks are not accessible, as we must try to judge
``Waverley'' (readers)
like readers inured to much fiction and much criticism, we must confess, no doubt, that the commencement has the faults which the first reviewers detected, and it which Scott acknowledged. He (Scott) is decidedly slow in getting to business, as they say; he (Scott) began with more of conscious ethical purpose than he (Scott) went on, and his (Scott) banter is poor. But when once we enter the village of Tully-Veolan, the Magician finds his (Magician) wand. Each picture of place or person tells,--the old butler, the daft Davie Gellatley, the solemn and chivalrous Baron, the pretty natural girl, the various lairds, the factor Macwheeble,--all at once become living people, and friends whom we can never lose. The creative fire of Shakspeare lives again. The Highlanders--Evan Dhu, Donald Bean Lean, his (Dhu) charming daughter, Callum Beg, and all the rest--are as natural as the Lowlanders. In Fergus and Flora we feel, indeed, at first, that the author has left his (author) experience behind, and is giving us creatures of fancy. But they too become human and natural,--Fergus in his (Fergus) moods of anger, ambition, and final courageous resignation; Flora, in her (Flora) grief. As for Waverley, his (Waverley) creator was no doubt too hard on him (Waverley). Among the brave we hear that he (Waverley) was one of the bravest, though Scott always wrote his (Scott) battlepieces in a manner to suggest no discomfort, and does not give us particular details of Waverley's prowess. He (Scott) has spirit enough, this
``sneaking piece of imbecility,'' (He)
as he (Scott) shows in his (Scott) quarrel with Fergus, on the march to Derby. Waverley, that creature of romance, considered as a lover, is really not romantic enough. He (Waverley) loved Rose because she (Flora) loved him (Waverley),--which is confessed to be unheroic behaviour. Scott, in
``Waverley,'' (Scott/Walter/Walter Scott)
certainly does not linger over love-scenes. With Mr. Ruskin, we may say:
``Let it not be thought for an instant that the slight and sometimes scornful glance with which Scott passes over scenes, which a novelist of our own day would have analyzed with the airs of a philosopher, and painted with the curiosity of a gossip, indicates any absence in his (philosopher) heart of sympathy with the great and sacred elements of personal happiness.'' (Mr. Ruskin)
But his (Ruskin) mind entertained other themes of interest,
``loyalty, patriotism, piety.'' (Mr. Ruskin)
On the other hand, it is necessary to differ from Mr. Ruskin when he (Ruskin) says that Scott ``never knew `lamor che move `l sol e l altre stelle.''' He (philosopher) whose heart was ``broken for two years,'' and retained the crack till his (Scott) dying day, he (Scott) who, when old and tired, and near his (Scott) death, was yet moved by the memory of the name which thirty years before he (Scott) had cut in Runic characters on the turf at the Castle-gate of St. Andrew, knew love too well to write of it much, or to speak of it at all. He (Andrew) had won his (Andrew) ideal as alone the ideal can be won; he (Andrew) never lost her (Ruskin): she (Ruskin) was with him (Andrew) always, because she (Ruskin) had been unattainable. ``There are few,'' he (Andrew) says, ``who have not, at one period of life, broken ties of love and friendship, secret disappointments of the heart, to mourn over,--and we know no book which recalls the memory of them more severely than `Julia de Roubigne.''' He (philosopher) could not be very eager to recall them, he (philosopher) who had so bitterly endured them, and because he (philosopher) had known and always knew
``lamor che move `l sol e laltre stelle,'' (he)
a seal was on his (Andrew) lips, a silence broken only by a caress of Di Vernon's.'

This apology we may make, if an apology be needed, for what modern readers may think the meagreness of the love-passages in Scott. He (Scott) does not deal in embraces and effusions, his (Scott) taste is too manly; he (Scott) does not dwell much on Love, because, like the shepherd in Theocritus, he (Scott) has found him (Scott) an inhabitant of the rocks. Moreover, when Scott began novel-writing, he (Scott) was as old as Thackeray when Thackeray said that while at work on a love-scene he (Thackeray) blushed so that you would think he (Thackeray) was going into an apoplexy.

stands by its pictures of manners, of character, by its humour and its tenderness, by its manly
