CHAPTER XXXIV

DESOLATION

Waverley riding post, as was the usual fashion of the period, without any adventure save one or two queries, which the talisman of his (Waverley) passport sufficiently answered, reached the borders of Scotland. Here he (Waverley) heard the tidings of the decisive battle of Culloden. It was no more than he (Waverley) had long expected, though the success at Falkirk had thrown a faint and setting gleam over the arms of the Chevalier. Yet it came upon him (Chevalier) like a shock, by which he (Chevalier) was for a time altogether unmanned. The generous, the courteous, the noble-minded adventurer was then a fugitive, with a price upon his (adventurer) head; his (adventurer) adherents, so brave, so enthusiastic, so faithful, were dead, imprisoned, or exiled. Where, now, was the exalted and high-souled Fergus, if, indeed, he (Fergus) had survived the night at Clifton? Where the pure-hearted and primitive Baron of Bradwardine, whose foibles seemed foils to set off the disinterestedness of his (Baron) disposition, the genuine goodness of his (Baron) heart, and his (Baron) unshaken courage? Those who clung for support to these fallen columns, Rose and Flora, where were they to be sought, and in what distress must not the loss of their natural protectors have involved them? Of Flora he (Rose) thought with the regard of a brother for a sister; of Rose with a sensation yet more deep and tender. It might be still his (Rose) fate to supply the want of those guardians they had lost. Agitated by these thoughts he (Rose) precipitated his (Rose) journey.

When he (Rose) arrived in Edinburgh, where his (Rose) inquiries must necessarily commence, he (Rose) felt the full difficulty of his (Rose) situation. Many inhabitants of that city had seen and known him (Rose) as Edward Waverley; how, then, could he (Rose) avail himself of a passport as Francis Stanley? He (Stanley) resolved, therefore, to avoid all company, and to move northward as soon as possible. He (Stanley) was, however, obliged to wait a day or two in expectation of a letter from Colonel Talbot, and he (Talbot) was also to leave his (Talbot) own address, under his (Talbot) feigned character, at a place agreed upon. With this latter purpose he (Talbot) sallied out in the dusk through the well-known streets, carefully shunning observation, but in vain: one of the first persons whom he (Talbot) met at once recognised him (Talbot). It was Mrs. Flockhart, Fergus Mac-Ivor's good-humoured landlady.

`Gude guide us, Mr. Waverley, is this you? na, ye needna be feared for me. I wad betray nae gentleman in your circumstances. Eh, lack-a-day! lack-a-day! here's a change o' markets; how merry Colonel Mac-Ivor and you used to be in our house!' And the good-natured widow shed a few natural tears. As there was no resisting her (widow) claim of acquaintance, Waverley acknowledged it with a good grace, as well as the danger of his (Waverley) own situation. `As it's near the darkening, sir, wad ye just step in by to our house and tak a dish o' tea? and I am sure if ye like to sleep in the little room, I wad tak care ye are no disturbed, and naebody wad ken ye; for Kate and Matty, the limmers, gaed aff wi' twa o' Hawley's dragoons, and I hae twa new queans instead o' them.'

Waverley accepted her (Kate) invitation, and engaged her (Kate) lodging for a night or two, satisfied he (Waverley) should be safer in the house of this simple creature than anywhere else. When he (Waverley) entered the parlour his (Waverley) heart swelled to see Fergus's bonnet, with the white cockade, hanging beside the little mirror.

`Ay,' said Mrs. Flockhart, sighing, as she (Flockhart) observed the direction of his (Waverley) eyes, `the puir Colonel bought a new ane just the day before they marched, and I winna let them tak that ane doun, but just to brush it ilka day mysell; and whiles I look at it till I just think I hear him (Colonel) cry to Callum to bring him (Colonel) his (Colonel) bonnet, as he (Colonel) used to do when he (Colonel) was ganging out. It's unco silly--the neighbours ca' me a Jacobite, but they may say their say--I am sure it's no for that--but he (Colonel) was as kind-hearted a gentleman as ever lived, and as weel-fa'rd too. Oh, dye ken, sir, when he (ken) is to suffer?'

`Suffer! Good heaven! Why, where is he (ken)?'

`Eh, Lord's sake! dye no ken? The poor Hieland body, Dugald Mahony, cam here a while syne, wi' ane o' his (Mahony) arms cuttit off, and a sair clour in the head--ye'll mind Dugald, he (Mahony) carried aye an axe on his (Mahony) shouther--and he (Mahony) cam here just begging, as I may say, for something to eat. Aweel, he (Mahony) tauld us the Chief, as they ca'd him (Chief) -LRB-but I aye ca' him (Chief) the Colonel-RRB-, and Ensign Maccombich, that ye mind weel, were taen somewhere beside the English border, when it was sae dark that his (Maccombich) folk never missed him (Maccombich) till it was ower late, and they were like to gang clean daft. And he (Maccombich) said that little Callum Beg -LRB-he (Maccombich) was a bauld mischievous callant that-RRB- and your honour were killed that same night in the tuilzie, and mony mae braw men. But he (Maccombich) grat when he (Maccombich) spak o' the Colonel, ye never saw the like. And now the word gangs the Colonel is to be tried, and to suffer wi' them that were taen at Carlisle.'

`And his (Colonel) sister?'

`Ay, that they ca'd the Lady Flora--weel, she (Flora)'s away up to Carlisle to him (Carlisle), and lives wi' some grand Papist lady thereabouts to be near him (Carlisle).'

`And,' said Edward, `the other young lady?'

`Whilk other? I ken only of ae sister the Colonel had.'

`I mean Miss Bradwardine,' said Edward.

`Ou, ay; the laird's daughter' said his (Edward) landlady. `She (daughter) was a very bonny lassie, poor thing, but far shyer than Lady Flora.'

`Where is she (Flora), for God's sake?'

`Ou, wha kens where ony o' them is now? puir things, they're sair taen doun for their white cockades and their white roses; but she (Flora) gaed north to her (Flora) father's in Perthshire, when the government troops cam back to Edinbro'. There was some prettymen amang them, and ane Major Whacker was quartered on me, a very ceevil gentleman,--but O, Mr. Waverley, he (Waverley) was naething sae weel fa'rd as the puir Colonel.'

`Do you know what is become of Miss Bradwardine's father?'

`The auld laird? na, naebody kens that. But they say he (laird) fought very hard in that bluidy battle at Inverness; and Deacon Clank, the whit-iron smith, says that the government folk are sair agane him (Deacon) for having been out twice; and troth he (Deacon) might hae taen warning, but there's nae Me like an auld fule. The puir Colonel was only out ance.'

Such conversation contained almost all the good-natured widow knew of the fate of her (widow) late lodgers and acquaintances; but it was enough to determine Edward, at all hazards, to proceed instantly to Tully-Veolan, where he (Edward) concluded he (Edward) should see, or at least hear, something of Rose. He (Rose) therefore left a letter for Colonel Talbot at the place agreed upon, signed by his (Colonel) assumed name, and giving for his (Colonel) address the post-town next to the Baron's residence.

From Edinburgh to Perth he (Colonel) took post-horses, resolving to make the rest of his (Colonel) journey on foot; a mode of travelling to which he (Colonel) was partial, and which had the advantage of permitting a deviation from the road when he (Colonel) saw parties of military at a distance. His (Colonel) campaign had considerably strengthened his (Colonel) constitution and improved his (Colonel) habits of enduring fatigue. His (Colonel) baggage he (Colonel) sent before him (Colonel) as opportunity occurred.

As he (Colonel) advanced northward, the traces of war became visible. Broken carriages, dead horses, unroofed cottages, trees felled for palisades, and bridges destroyed or only partially repaired--all indicated the movements of hostile armies. In those places where the gentry were attached to the Stuart cause, their houses seemed dismantled or deserted, the usual course of what may be called ornamental labour was totally interrupted, and the inhabitants were seen gliding about, with fear, sorrow, and dejection on their faces.

It was evening when he (Stuart) approached the village of Tully-Veolan, with feelings and sentiments--how different from those which attended his (Stuart) first entrance! Then, life was so new to him (Stuart) that a dull or disagreeable day was one of the greatest misfortunes which his (Stuart) imagination anticipated, and it seemed to him (Stuart) that his (Stuart) time ought only to be consecrated to elegant or amusing study, and relieved by social or youthful frolic. Now, how changed! how saddened, yet how elevated was his (Stuart) character, within the course of a very few months! Danger and misfortune are rapid, though severe teachers. `A sadder and a wiser man,' he (man) felt in internal confidence and mental dignity a compensation for the gay dreams which in his (man) case experience had so rapidly dissolved.

As he (man) approached the village he (man) saw, with surprise and anxiety, that a party of soldiers were quartered near it, and, what was worse, that they seemed stationary there. This he (man) conjectured from a few tents which he (man) beheld glimmering upon what was called the Common Moor. To avoid the risk of being stopped and questioned in a place where he (Moor) was so likely to be recognised, he (Moor) made a large circuit, altogether avoiding the hamlet, and approaching the upper gate of the avenue by a by-path well known to him (Moor). A single glance announced that great changes had taken place. One half of the gate, entirely destroyed and split up for firewood, lay in piles, ready to be taken away; the other swung uselessly about upon its loosened hinges. The battlements above the gate were broken and thrown down, and the carved bears, which were said to have done sentinel's duty upon the top for centuries, now, hurled from their posts, lay among the rubbish. The avenue was cruelly wasted. Several large trees were felled and left lying across the path; and the cattle of the villagers, and the more rude hoofs of dragoon horses, had poached into black mud the verdant turf which Waverley had so much admired.

Upon entering the court-yard, Edward saw the fears realised which these circumstances had excited. The place had been sacked by the King's troops, who, in wanton mischief, had even attempted to burn it; and though the thickness of the walls had resisted the fire, unless to a partial extent, the stables and out-houses were totally consumed. The towers and pinnacles of the main building were scorched and blackened; the pavement of the court broken and shattered, the doors torn down entirely, or hanging by a single hinge, the windows dashed in and demolished, and the court strewed with articles of furniture broken into fragments. The accessaries of ancient distinction, to which the Baron, in the pride of his (Baron) heart, had attached so much importance and veneration, were treated with peculiar contumely. The fountain was demolished, and the spring which had supplied it now flooded the court-yard. The stone basin seemed to be destined for a drinking-trough for cattle, from the manner in which it was arranged upon the ground. The whole tribe of bears, large and small, had experienced as little favour as those at the head of the avenue, and one or two of the family pictures, which seemed to have served as targets for the soldiers, lay on the ground in tatters. With an aching heart, as may well be imagined, Edward viewed this wreck of a mansion so respected. But his (Edward) anxiety to learn the fate of the proprietors, and his (Edward) fears as to what that fate might be, increased with every step. When he (Edward) entered upon the terrace new scenes of desolation were visible. The balustrade was broken down, the walls destroyed, the borders overgrown with weeds, and the fruit-trees cut down or grubbed up. In one compartment of this old-fashioned garden were two immense horse-chestnut trees, of whose size the Baron was particularly vain; too lazy, perhaps, to cut them down, the spoilers, with malevolent ingenuity, had mined them and placed a quantity of gunpowder in the cavity. One had been shivered to pieces by the explosion, and the fragments lay scattered around, encumbering the ground it had so long shadowed. The other mine had been more partial in its effect. About one-fourth of the trunk of the tree was torn from the mass, which, mutilated and defaced on the one side, still spread on the other its ample and undiminished boughs. -LSB-Footnote: A pair of chestnut trees, destroyed, the one entirely and the other in part, by such a mischievous and wanton act of revenge, grew at Invergarry Castle, the fastness of MacDonald of Glengarry.-RSB-

Amid these general marks of ravage, there were some which more particularly addressed the feelings of Waverley. Viewing the front of the building thus wasted and defaced, his (its) eyes naturally sought the little balcony which more properly belonged to Rose's apartment, her (MacDonald) troisieme, or rather cinquieme, etage. It was easily discovered, for beneath it lay the stage-flowers and shrubs with which it was her (MacDonald) pride to decorate it, and which had been hurled from the bartizan; several of her (MacDonald) books were mingled with broken flower-pots and other remnants. Among these Waverley distinguished one of his (Waverley) own, a small copy of Ariosto, and gathered it as a treasure, though wasted by the wind and rain.

While, plunged in the sad reflections which the scene excited, he (Waverley) was looking around for some one who might explain the fate of the inhabitants, he (Waverley) heard a voice from the interior of the building singing, in well-remembered accents, an old Scottish song:--

They came upon us in the night, And brake my bower and slew my knight; My servants a' for life did flee, And left us in extremitie.

They slew my knight, to me sae dear; They slew my knight, and drave his (knight) gear; The moon may set, the sun may rise, But a deadly sleep has closed his (knight) eyes.

-LSB-Footnote: The first three couplets are from an old ballad, called the Border Widow's Lament.-RSB-

`Alas,' thought Edward, `is it thou? Poor helpless being, art thou alone left, to gibber and moan, and fill with thy wild and unconnected scraps of minstrelsy the halls that protected thee?' He (Edward) then called, first low, and then louder, `Davie--Davie Gellatley!'

The poor simpleton showed himself from among the ruins of a sort of greenhouse, that once terminated what was called the terrace-walk, but at first sight of a stranger retreated, as if in terror. Waverley, remembering his (Waverley) habits, began to whistle a tune to which he (Waverley) was partial, which Davie had expressed great pleasure in listening to, and had picked up from him (Davie) by the ear. Our hero's minstrelsy no more equalled that of Blondel than poor Davie resembled Coeur de Lion; but the melody had the same effect of producing recognition. Davie again stole from his (Davie) lurking-place, but timidly, while Waverley, afraid of frightening him (Waverley), stood making the most encouraging signals he (Waverley) could devise. `It's his (Waverley) ghaist,' muttered Davie; yet, coming nearer, he (Davie) seemed to acknowledge his (Davie) living acquaintance. The poor fool himself appeared the ghost of what he (Davie) had been. The peculiar dress in which he (Davie) had been attired in better days showed only miserable rags of its whimsical finery, the lack of which was oddly supplied by the remnants of tapestried hangings, window-curtains, and shreds of pictures with which he (Davie) had bedizened his (Davie) tatters. His (Davie) face, too, had lost its vacant and careless air, and the poor creature looked hollow-eyed, meagre, half-starved, and nervous to a pitiable degree. After long hesitation, he (Davie) at length approached Waverley with some confidence, stared him (Davie) sadly in the face, and said, `A' dead and gane--a' dead and gane.'

`Who are dead?' said Waverley, forgetting the incapacity of Davie to hold any connected discourse.

`Baron, and Bailie, and Saunders Saunderson, and Lady Rose that sang sae sweet--a' dead and gane--dead and gane;

But follow, follow me, While glowworms light the lea, I'll show ye where the dead should be-- Each in his (Bailie) shroud, While winds pipe loud, And the red moon peeps dim through the cloud. Follow, follow me; Brave should he (Bailie) be That treads by night the dead man's lea.'

With these words, chanted in a wild and earnest tone, he (Bailie) made a sign to Waverley to follow him (Bailie), and walked rapidly towards the bottom of the garden, tracing the bank of the stream which, it may be remembered, was its eastern boundary. Edward, over whom an involuntary shuddering stole at the import of his (Edward) words, followed him (Edward) in some hope of an explanation. As the house was evidently deserted, he (Edward) could not expect to find among the ruins any more rational informer.

Davie, walking very fast, soon reached the extremity of the garden, and scrambled over the ruins of the wall that once had divided it from the wooded glen in which the old tower of Tully-Veolan was situated. He (Davie) then jumped down into the bed of the stream, and, followed by Waverley, proceeded at a great pace, climbing over some fragments of rock and turning with difficulty round others. They passed beneath the ruins of the castle; Waverley followed, keeping up with his (Waverley) guide with difficulty, for the twilight began to fall. Following the descent of the stream a little lower, he (Waverley) totally lost him (Waverley), but a twinkling light which he (Waverley) now discovered among the tangled copse-wood and bushes seemed a surer guide. He (Waverley) soon pursued a very uncouth path; and by its guidance at length reached the door of a wretched hut. A fierce barking of dogs was at first heard, but it stilled at his (Waverley) approach. A voice sounded from within, and he (Waverley) held it most prudent to listen before he (Waverley) advanced.

`Wha hast thou brought here, thou unsonsy villain, thou?' said an old woman, apparently in great indignation. He (Waverley) heard Davie Gellatley in answer whistle a part of the tune by which he (Waverley) had recalled himself to the simpleton's memory, and had now no hesitation to knock at the door. There was a dead silence instantly within, except the deep growling of the dogs; and he (Waverley) next heard the mistress of the hut approach the door, not probably for the sake of undoing a latch, but of fastening a bolt. To prevent this Waverley lifted the latch himself.

In front was an old wretched-looking woman, exclaiming, `Wha comes into folk's houses in this gate, at this time o' the night?' On one side, two grim and half-starved deer greyhounds laid aside their ferocity at his (Waverley) appearance, and seemed to recognise him (Waverley). On the other side, half concealed by the open door, yet apparently seeking that concealment reluctantly, with a cocked pistol in his (Waverley) right hand and his (Waverley) left in the act of drawing another from his (Waverley) belt, stood a tall bony gaunt figure in the remnants of a faded uniform and a beard of three weeks' growth. It was the Baron of Bradwardine. It is unnecessary to add, that he (Baron) threw aside his (Baron) weapon and greeted Waverley with a hearty embrace.

CHAPTER XXXV

COMPARING OF NOTES

Thearon's story was short, when divested of the adages and commonplaces, Latin, English, and Scotch, with which his (Baron) erudition garnished it. He (Baron) insisted much upon his (Baron) grief at the loss of Edward and of Glennaquoich, fought the fields of Falkirk and Culloden, and related how, after all was lost in the last battle, he (Baron) had returned home, under the idea of more easily finding shelter among his (Baron) own tenants and on his (Baron) own estate than elsewhere. A party of soldiers had been sent to lay waste his (Baron) property, for clemency was not the order of the day. Their proceedings, however, were checked by an order from the civil court. The estate, it was found, might not be forfeited to the crown to the prejudice of Malcolm Bradwardine of Inch-Grabbit, the heir-male, whose claim could not be prejudiced by the Baron's attainder, as deriving no right through him (Baron), and who, therefore, like other heirs of entail in the same situation, entered upon possession. But, unlike many in similar circumstances, the new laird speedily showed that he (laird) intended utterly to exclude his (laird) predecessor from all benefit or advantage in the estate, and that it was his (laird) purpose to avail himself of the old Baron's evil fortune to the full extent. This was the more ungenerous, as it was generally known that, from a romantic idea of not prejudicing this young man's right as heir-male, the Baron had refrained from settling his (Baron) estate on his (Baron) daughter.

This selfish injustice was resented by the country people, who were partial to their old master, and irritated against his (master) successor. In the Baron's own words, `The matter did not coincide with the feelings of the commons of Bradwardine, Mr. Waverley; and the tenants were slack and repugnant in payment of their mails and duties; and when my kinsman came to the village wi' the new factor, Mr. James Howie, to lift the rents, some wanchancy person--I suspect John Heatherblutter, the auld gamekeeper, that was out wi' me in the year fifteen--fired a shot at him (Heatherblutter) in the gloaming, whereby he (Heatherblutter) was so affrighted, that I may say with Tullius In Catilinam,

``Abiit, evasit, erupit, effugit.'' (Tullius)
He (Heatherblutter) fled, sir, as one may say, incontinent to Stirling. And now he (Heatherblutter) hath advertised the estate for sale, being himself the last substitute in the entail. And if I were to lament about sic matters, this would grieve me mair than its passing from my immediate possession, whilk, by the course of nature, must have happened in a few years; whereas now it passes from the lineage that should have possessed it in sæcula sæculorum. But God's will be done, humana perpessi sumus. Sir John of Bradwardine--Black Sir John, as he (John) is called--who was the common ancestor of our house and the Inch-Grabbits, little thought such a person would have sprung from his (John) loins. Mean time, he (John) has accused me to some of the primates, the rulers for the time, as if I were a cut-throat, and an abettor of bravoes and assassinates and coupe-jarrets. And they have sent soldiers here to abide on the estate, and hunt me like a partridge upon the mountains, as Scripture says of good King David, or like our valiant Sir William Wallace--not that I bring myself into comparison with either. I thought, when I heard you at the door, they had driven the auld deer to his (Wallace) den at last; and so I e'en proposed to die at bay, like a buck of the first head. But now, Janet, canna ye gie us something for supper?'

`Ou ay, sir, I'll brander the moor-fowl that John Heatherblutter brought in this morning; and ye see puir Davie's roasting the black hen's eggs. I daur say, Mr. Wauverley, ye never kend that a' the eggs that were sae weel roasted at supper in the Ha'-house were aye turned by our Davie? there's no the like o' him (Davie) ony gate for powtering wi' his (Davie) fingers amang the het peat-ashes and roasting eggs.' Davie all this while lay with his (Davie) nose almost in the fire, nuzzling among the ashes, kicking his (Davie) heels, mumbling to himself, turning the eggs as they lay in the hot embers, as if to confute the proverb, that `there goes reason to roasting of eggs,' and justify the eulogium which poor Janet poured out upon

Him (Davie) whom she (Janet) loved, her (Janet) idiot boy.

`Davie's no sae silly as folk tak him (Davie) for, Mr. Wauverley; he (Wauverley) wadna hae brought you here unless he (Wauverley) had kend ye was a friend to his (Wauverley) Honour; indeed the very dogs kend ye, Mr. Wauverley, for ye was aye kind to beast and body. I can tell you a story o' Davie, wi' his (Davie) Honour's leave. His (Davie) Honour, ye see, being under hiding in thae sair times--the mair's the pity--he (Davie) lies a' day, and whiles a' night, in the cove in the dern hag; but though it's a bieldy eneugh bit, and the auld gudeman o' Corse-Cleugh has panged it wi' a kemple o' strae amaist, yet when the country's quiet, and the night very cauld, his (Davie) Honour whiles creeps doun here to get a warm at the ingle and a sleep amang the blankets, and gangs awa in the morning. And so, ae morning, siccan a fright as I got! Twa unlucky red-coats were up for black-fishing, or some siccan ploy--for the neb o' them's never out o' mischief--and they just got a glisk o' his (Davie) Honour as he (Davie) gaed into the wood, and banged aff a gun at him (Davie). I out like a jer-falcon, and cried--

``Wad they shoot an honest woman's poor innocent bairn?'' (I)
And I fleyt at them, and threepit it was my son; and they damned and swuir at me that it was the auld rebel, as the villains ca'd his (rebel) Honour; and Davie was in the wood, and heard the tuilzie, and he (Davie), just out o' his (Davie) ain head, got up the auld grey mantle that his (Davie) Honour had flung off him (Davie) to gang the faster, and he (Davie) cam out o' the very same bit o' the wood, majoring and looking about sae like his (Davie) Honour, that they were clean beguiled, and thought they had letten aff their gun at crack-brained Sawney, as they ca' him (Davie); and they gae me saxpence, and twa saumon fish, to say naething about it. Na, na, Davie's no just like other folk, puir fallow; but he (Davie)'s no sae silly as folk tak him (Davie) for. But, to be sure, how can we do eneugh for his (Davie) Honour, when we and ours have lived on his (Davie) ground this twa hundred years; and when he (Davie) keepit my puir Jamie at school and college, and even at the Ha'-house, till he (Ha) gaed to a better place; and when he (Ha) saved me frae being taen to Perth as a witch--Lord forgie them that would touch sic a puir silly auld body!--and has maintained puir Davie at heck and manger maist feck o' his (Davie) life?'

Waverley at length found an opportunity to interrupt Janet's narrative by an inquiry after Miss Bradwardine.

`She (Bradwardine)'s weel and safe, thank God! at the Duchran,' answered the Baron; `the laird's distantly related to us, and more nearly to my chaplain, Mr. Rubrick; and, though he (Rubrick) be of Whig principles, yet he (Rubrick)'s not forgetful of auld friendship at this time. The Bailie's doing what he (Bailie) can to save something out of the wreck for puir Rose; but I doubt, I doubt, I shall never see her (Bradwardine) again, for I maun lay my banes in some far country.'

`Hout na, your Honour,' said old Janet, `ye were just as ill aff in the feifteen, and got the bonnie baronie back, an' a'. And now the eggs is ready, and the muir-cock's brandered, and there's ilk ane a trencher and some saut, and the heel o' the white loaf that cam frae the Bailie's, and there's plenty o' brandy in the greybeard that Luckie Maclearie sent doun, and winna ye be suppered like princes?'

`I wish one Prince, at least, of our acquaintance may be no worse off,' said the Baron to Waverley, who joined him (Baron) in cordial hopes for the safety of the unfortunate Chevalier.

They then began to talk of their future prospects. The Baron's plan was very simple. It was, to escape to France, where, by the interest of his (Baron) old friends, he (Baron) hoped to get some military employment, of which he (Baron) still conceived himself capable. He (Baron) invited Waverley to go with him (Baron), a proposal in which he (Baron) acquiesced, providing the interest of Colonel Talbot should fail in procuring his (Talbot) pardon. Tacitly he (Talbot) hoped the Baron would sanction his (Baron) addresses to Rose, and give him (Baron) a right to assist him (Baron) in his (Baron) exile; but he (Baron) forbore to speak on this subject until his (Baron) own fate should be decided. They then talked of Glennaquoich, for whom the Baron expressed great anxiety, although, he (Baron) observed, he (Baron) was `the very Achilles of Horatius Flaccus,--

Impiger, iracundus, inexorabilis, acer; which,' he (Baron) continued, `has been thus rendered -LRB-vernacularly-RRB- by Struan Robertson:--

A fiery etter-cap, a fractious chiel, As het as ginger, and as stieve as steel.'

Flora had a large and unqualified share of the good old man's sympathy.

It was now wearing late. Old Janet got into some kind of kennel behind the hallan; Davie had been long asleep and snoring between Ban and Buscar. These dogs had followed him (Davie) to the hut after the mansion-house was deserted, and there constantly resided; and their ferocity, with the old woman's reputation of being a witch, contributed a good deal to keep visitors from the glen. With this view, Bailie Macwheeble provided Janet underhand with meal for their maintenance, and also with little articles of luxury for his (Macwheeble) patron's use, in supplying which much precaution was necessarily used. After some compliments, the Baron occupied his (Baron) usual couch, and Waverley reclined in an easy chair of tattered velvet, which had once garnished the state bed-room of Tully-Veolan -LRB-for the furniture of this mansion was now scattered through all the cottages in the vicinity-RRB-, and went to sleep as comfortably as if he (Waverley) had been in a bed of down.

CHAPTER XXXVI

MORE EXPLANATION

With the first dawn of day, old Janet was scuttling about the house to wake the Baron, who usually slept sound and heavily.

`I must go back,' he (Baron) said to Waverley, `to my cove; will you walk down the glen wi' me?' They went out together, and followed a narrow and entangled foot-path, which the occasional passage of anglers or wood-cutters had traced by the side of the stream. On their way the Baron explained to Waverley that he (Baron) would be under no danger in remaining a day or two at Tully-Veolan, and even in being seen walking about, if he (Baron) used the precaution of pretending that he (Baron) was looking at the estate as agent or surveyor for an English gentleman who designed to be purchaser. With this view he (gentleman) recommended to him (gentleman) to visit the Bailie, who still lived at the factor's house, called Little Veolan, about a mile from the village, though he (Bailie) was to remove at next term. Stanley's passport would be an answer to the officer who commanded the military; and as to any of the country people who might recognise Waverley, the Baron assured him (Baron) he (Baron) was in no danger of being betrayed by them.

`I believe,' said the old man, `half the people of the barony know that their poor auld laird is somewhere hereabout; for I see they do not suffer a single bairn to come here a bird-nesting; a practice whilk, when I was in full possession of my power as baron, I was unable totally to inhibit. Nay, I often find bits of things in my way, that the poor bodies, God help them! leave there, because they think they may be useful to me. I hope they will get a wiser master, and as kind a one as I was.'

A natural sigh closed the sentence; but the quiet equanimity with which the Baron endured his (Baron) misfortunes had something in it venerable and even sublime. There was no fruitless repining, no turbid melancholy; he (Baron) bore his (Baron) lot, and the hardships which it involved, with a good-humored, though serious composure, and used no violent language against the prevailing party.

`I did what I thought my duty,' said the good old man, `and questionless they are doing what they think theirs. It grieves me sometimes to look upon these blackened walls of the house of my ancestors; but doubtless officers cannot always keep the soldier's hand from depredation and spuilzie, and Gustavus Adolphus himself, as ye may read in Colonel Munro his (Munro)

``Expedition with the Worthy Scotch Regiment called Mackay's Regiment'' (Colonel Munro)
did often permit it. Indeed I have myself seen as sad sights as Tully-Veolan now is when I served with the Marechal Duke of Berwick. To be sure we may say with Virgilius Maro, Fuimus Troes--and there's the end of an auld sang. But houses and families and men have a' stood lang eneugh when they have stood till they fall with honour; and now I hae gotten a house that is not unlike a domus ultima'--they were now standing below a steep rock. `We poor Jacobites,' continued the Baron, looking up, `are now like the conies in Holy Scripture -LRB-which the great traveller Pococke calleth Jerboa-RRB-, a feeble people, that make our abode in the rocks. So, fare you well, my good lad, till we meet at Janet's in the even; for I must get into my Patmos, which is no easy matter for my auld stiff limbs.'

With that he (lad) began to ascend the rock, striding, with the help of his (lad) hands, from one precarious footstep to another, till he (lad) got about half-way up, where two or three bushes concealed the mouth of a hole, resembling an oven, into which the Baron insinuated, first his (Baron) head and shoulders, and then, by slow gradation, the rest of his (Baron) long body; his (Baron) legs and feet finally disappearing, coiled up like a huge snake entering his (Baron) retreat, or a long pedigree introduced with care and difficulty into the narrow pigeon-hole of an old cabinet. Waverley had the curiosity to clamber up and look in upon him (Waverley) in his (Waverley) den, as the lurking-place might well be termed. Upon the whole, he (Waverley) looked not unlike that ingenious puzzle called `a reel in a bottle,' the marvel of children -LRB-and of some grown people too, myself for one-RRB-, who can neither comprehend the mystery how it has got in or how it is to be taken out. The cave was very narrow, too low in the roof to admit of his (Waverley) standing, or almost of his (Waverley) sitting up, though he (Waverley) made some awkward attempts at the latter posture. His (Waverley) sole amusement was the perusal of his (Waverley) old friend Titus Livius, varied by occasionally scratching Latin proverbs and texts of Scripture with his (Waverley) knife on the roof and walls of his (Waverley) fortalice, which were of sandstone. As the cave was dry, and filled with clean straw and withered fern, `it made,' as he (Waverley) said, coiling himself up with an air of snugness and comfort which contrasted strangely with his (Waverley) situation, `unless when the wind was due north, a very passable gite for an old soldier.' Neither, as he (soldier) observed, was he (soldier) without sentries for the purpose of reconnoitring. Davie and his (Davie) mother were constantly on the watch to discover and avert danger; and it was singular what instances of address seemed dictated by the instinctive attachment of the poor simpleton when his (Davie) patron's safety was concerned.

With Janet, Edward now sought an interview. He (Edward) had recognised her (Janet) at first sight as the old woman who had nursed him (Edward) during his (Edward) sickness after his (Edward) delivery from Gifted Gilfillan. The hut also, although a little repaired and somewhat better furnished, was certainly the place of his (Edward) confinement; and he (Edward) now recollected on the common moor of Tully-Veolan the trunk of a large decayed tree, called the try sting-tree, which he (Edward) had no doubt was the same at which the Highlanders rendezvoused on that memorable night. All this he (Edward) had combined in his (Edward) imagination the night before; but reasons which may probably occur to the reader prevented him (Edward) from catechising Janet in the presence of the Baron.

He (Baron) now commenced the task in good earnest; and the first question was, Who was the young lady that visited the hut during his (Baron) illness? Janet paused for a little; and then observed, that to keep the secret now would neither do good nor ill to anybody.

`It was just a leddy that hasna her (Janet) equal in the world--Miss Rose Bradwardine!'

`Then Miss Rose was probably also the author of my deliverance,' inferred Waverley, delighted at the confirmation of an idea which local circumstances had already induced him (Waverley) to entertain.

`I wot weel, Mr. Wauverley, and that was she (Rose) e'en; but sair, sair angry and affronted wad she (Rose) hae been, puir thing, if she (Rose) had thought ye had been ever to ken a word about the matter; for she (Rose) gar'd me speak aye Gaelic when ye was in hearing, to mak ye trow we were in the Hielands. I can speak it weil eneugh, for my mother was a Hieland woman.'

A few more questions now brought out the whole mystery respecting Waverley's deliverance from the bondage in which he (Waverley) left Cairnvreckan. Never did music sound sweeter to an amateur than the drowsy tautology with which old Janet detailed every circumstance thrilled upon the ears of Waverley. But my reader is not a lover and I must spare his (reader) patience, by attempting to condense within reasonable compass the narrative which old Janet spread through a harangue of nearly two hours.

When Waverley communicated to Fergus the letter he (Waverley) had received from Rose Bradwardine by Davie Gellatley, giving an account of Tully-Veolan being occupied by a small party of soldiers, that circumstance had struck upon the busy and active mind of the Chieftain. Eager to distress and narrow the posts of the enemy, desirous to prevent their establishing a garrison so near him (Chieftain), and willing also to oblige the Baron--for he (Baron) often had the idea of marriage with Rose floating through his (Rose) brain--he (Rose) resolved to send some of his (Rose) people to drive out the red-coats and to bring Rose to Glennaquoich. But just as he (Rose) had ordered Evan with a small party on this duty, the news of Cope's having marched into the Highlands, to meet and disperse the forces of the Chevalier ere they came to a head, obliged him (Chevalier) to join the standard with his (Chevalier) whole forces.

He (Chevalier) sent to order Donald Bean to attend him (Chevalier); but that cautious freebooter, who well understood the value of a separate command, instead of joining, sent various apologies which the pressure of the times compelled Fergus to admit as current, though not without the internal resolution of being revenged on him (Fergus) for his (Fergus) procrastination, time and place convenient. However, as he (Fergus) could not amend the matter, he (Fergus) issued orders to Donald to descend into the Low Country, drive the soldiers from Tully-Veolan, and, paying all respect to the mansion of the Baron, to take his (Baron) abode somewhere near it, for protection of his (Baron) daughter and family, and to harass and drive away any of the armed volunteers or small parties of military which he (Baron) might find moving about the vicinity. As this charge formed a sort of roving commission, which Donald proposed to interpret in the way most advantageous to himself, as he (Donald) was relieved from the immediate terrors of Fergus, and as he (Fergus) had, from former secret services, some interest in the councils of the Chevalier, he (Chevalier) resolved to make hay while the sun shone. He (Chevalier) achieved without difficulty the task of driving the soldiers from Tully-Veolan; but, although he (Chevalier) did not venture to encroach upon the interior of the family, or to disturb Miss Rose, being unwilling to make himself a powerful enemy in the Chevalier's army, For well he (Chevalier) knew the Baron's wrath was deadly; yet he (Chevalier) set about to raise contributions and exactions upon the tenantry, and otherwise to turn the war to his (Chevalier) own advantage. Meanwhile he (Chevalier) mounted the white cockade, and waited upon Rose with a pretext of great devotion for the service in which her (Rose) father was engaged, and many apologies for the freedom he (father) must necessarily use for the support of his (father) people. It was at this moment that Rose learned, by open-mouthed fame, with all sorts of exaggeration, that Waverley had killed the smith at Cairnvreckan, in an attempt to arrest him (Waverley); had been cast into a dungeon by Major Melville of Cairnvreckan, and was to be executed by martial law within three days. In the agony which these tidings excited she (Rose) proposed to Donald Bean the rescue of the prisoner. It was the very sort of service which he (Bean) was desirous to undertake, judging it might constitute a merit of such a nature as would make amends for any peccadilloes which he (Bean) might be guilty of in the country. He (Bean) had the art, however, pleading all the while duty and discipline, to hold off, until poor Rose, in the extremity of her (Rose) distress, offered to bribe him (Rose) to the enterprise with some valuable jewels which had been her (Rose) mother's.

Donald Bean, who had served in France, knew, and perhaps over-estimated, the value of these trinkets. But he (Bean) also perceived Rose's apprehensions of its being discovered that she (Rose) had parted with her (Rose) jewels for Waverley's liberation. Resolved this scruple should not part him (Waverley) and the treasure, he (Waverley) voluntarily offered to take an oath that he (Waverley) would never mention Miss Rose's share in the transaction; and, foreseeing convenience in keeping the oath and no probable advantage in breaking it, he (Waverley) took the engagement--in order, as he (Waverley) told his (Waverley) lieutenant, to deal handsomely by the young lady--in the only mode and form which, by a mental paction with himself, he (Waverley) considered as binding: he (Waverley) swore secrecy upon his (Waverley) drawn dirk. He (Waverley) was the more especially moved to this act of good faith by some attentions that Miss Bradwardine showed to his (Waverley) daughter Alice, which, while they gained the heart of the mountain damsel, highly gratified the pride of her (damsel) father. Alice, who could now speak a little English, was very communicative in return for Rose's kindness, readily confided to her (Alice) the whole papers respecting the intrigue with Gardiner's regiment, of which she (Alice) was the depositary, and as readily undertook, at her (Alice) instance, to restore them to Waverley without her (Alice) father's knowledge. For `they may oblige the bonnie young lady and the handsome young gentleman,' said Alice, `and what use has my father for a whin bits o' scarted paper?'

The reader is aware that she (Alice) took an opportunity of executing this purpose on the eve of Waverley's leaving the glen.

How Donald executed his (Donald) enterprise the reader is aware. But the expulsion of the military from Tully-Veolan had given alarm, and while he (Donald) was lying in wait for Gilfillan, a strong party, such as Donald did not care to face, was sent to drive back the insurgents in their turn, to encamp there, and to protect the country. The officer, a gentleman and a disciplinarian, neither intruded himself on Miss Bradwardine, whose unprotected situation he (officer) respected, nor permitted his (officer) soldiers to commit any breach of discipline. He (officer) formed a little camp upon an eminence near the house of Tully-Veolan, and placed proper guards at the passes in the vicinity. This unwelcome news reached Donald Bean Lean as he (Lean) was returning to Tully-Veolan. Determined, however, to obtain the guerdon of his (Lean) labour, he (Lean) resolved, since approach to Tully-Veolan was impossible, to deposit his (Lean) prisoner in Janet's cottage, a place the very existence of which could hardly have been suspected even by those who had long lived in the vicinity, unless they had been guided thither, and which was utterly unknown to Waverley himself. This effected, he (Lean) claimed and received his (Lean) reward. Waverley's illness was an event which deranged all their calculations. Donald was obliged to leave the neighbourhood with his (Donald) people, and to seek more free course for his (Donald) adventures elsewhere. At Rose's entreaty, he (Donald) left an old man, a herbalist, who was supposed to understand a little of medicine, to attend Waverley during his (Waverley) illness.

In the meanwhile, new and fearful doubts started in Rose's mind. They were suggested by old Janet, who insisted that, a reward having been offered for the apprehension of Waverley, and his (Rose) own personal effects being so valuable, there was no saying to what breach of faith Donald might be tempted. In an agony of grief and terror, Rose took the daring resolution of explaining to the Prince himself the danger in which Mr. Waverley stood, judging that, both as a politician and a man of honour and humanity, Charles Edward would interest himself to prevent his (Edward) falling into the hands of the opposite party. This letter she (Janet) at first thought of sending anonymously, but naturally feared it would not in that case be credited. She (Janet) therefore subscribed her (Janet) name, though with reluctance and terror, and consigned it in charge to a young man, who at leaving his (man) farm to join the Chevalier's army, made it his (man) petition to her (Janet) to have some sort of credentials to the adventurer, from whom he (man) hoped to obtain a commission.

The letter reached Charles Edward on his (Edward) descent to the Lowlands, and, aware of the political importance of having it supposed that he (Edward) was in correspondence with the English Jacobites, he (Edward) caused the most positive orders to be transmitted to Donald Bean Lean to transmit Waverley, safe and uninjured, in person or effects, to the governor of Doune Castle. The freebooter durst not disobey, for the army of the Prince was now so near him (Prince) that punishment might have followed; besides, he (Prince) was a politician as well as a robber, and was unwilling to cancel the interest created through former secret services by being refractory on this occasion. He (Prince) therefore made a virtue of necessity, and transmitted orders to his (Prince) lieutenant to convey Edward to Doune, which was safely accomplished in the mode mentioned in a former chapter. The governor of Doune was directed to send him (governor) to Edinburgh as a prisoner, because the Prince was apprehensive that Waverley, if set at liberty, might have resumed his (Prince) purpose of returning to England, without affording him (Prince) an opportunity of a personal interview. In this, indeed, he (Prince) acted by the advice of the Chieftain of Glennaquoich, with whom it may be remembered the Chevalier communicated upon the mode of disposing of Edward, though without telling him (Edward) how he (Edward) came to learn the place of his (Edward) confinement.

This, indeed, Charles Edward considered as a lady's secret; for although Rose's letter was couched in the most cautious and general terms, and professed to be written merely from motives of humanity and zeal for the Prince's service, yet she (lady) expressed so anxious a wish that she (lady) should not be known to have interfered, that the Chevalier was induced to suspect the deep interest which she (lady) took in Waverley's safety. This conjecture, which was well founded, led, however, to false inferences. For the emotion which Edward displayed on approaching Flora and Rose at the ball of Holyrood was placed by the Chevalier to the account of the latter; and he (Chevalier) concluded that the Baron's views about the settlement of his (Chevalier) property, or some such obstacle, thwarted their mutual inclinations. Common fame, it is true, frequently gave Waverley to Miss Mac-Ivor; but the Prince knew that common fame is very prodigal in such gifts; and, watching attentively the behaviour of the ladies towards Waverley, he (Prince) had no doubt that the young Englishman had no interest with Flora, and was beloved by Rose Bradwardine. Desirous to bind Waverley to his (Waverley) service, and wishing also to do a kind and friendly action, the Prince next assailed the Baron on the subject of settling his (Prince) estate upon his (Prince) daughter. Mr. Bradwardine acquiesced; but the consequence was that Fergus was immediately induced to prefer his (Fergus) double suit for a wife and an earldom, which the Prince rejected in the manner we have seen. The Chevalier, constantly engaged in his (Chevalier) own multiplied affairs, had not hitherto sought any explanation with Waverley, though often meaning to do so. But after Fergus's declaration he (Fergus) saw the necessity of appearing neutral between the rivals, devoutly hoping that the matter, which now seemed fraught with the seeds of strife, might be permitted to lie over till the termination of the expedition. When, on the march to Derby, Fergus, being questioned concerning his (Fergus) quarrel with Waverley, alleged as the cause that Edward was desirous of retracting the suit he (Edward) had made to his (Edward) sister, the Chevalier plainly told him (Chevalier) that he (Chevalier) had himself observed Miss Mac-Ivor's behaviour to Waverley, and that he (Chevalier) was convinced Fergus was under the influence of a mistake in judging of Waverley's conduct, who, he (Fergus) had every reason to believe, was engaged to Miss Bradwardine. The quarrel which ensued between Edward and the Chieftain is, I hope, still in the remembrance of the reader. These circumstances will serve to explain such points of our narrative as, according to the custom of story-tellers, we deemed it fit to leave unexplained, for the purpose of exciting the reader's curiosity.

When Janet had once finished the leading facts of this narrative, Waverley was easily enabled to apply the clue which they afforded to other mazes of the labyrinth in which he (Waverley) had been engaged. To Rose Bradwardine, then, he (Bradwardine) owed the life which he (Bradwardine) now thought he (Bradwardine) could willingly have laid down to serve her (Janet). A little reflection convinced him (Bradwardine), however, that to live for her (Janet) sake was more convenient and agreeable, and that, being possessed of independence, she (Janet) might share it with him (Bradwardine) either in foreign countries or in his (Bradwardine) own. The pleasure of being allied to a man of the Baron's high worth, and who was so much valued by his (Baron) uncle Sir Everard, was also an agreeable consideration, had anything been wanting to recommend the match. His (Baron) absurdities, which had appeared grotesquely ludicrous during his (Baron) prosperity, seemed, in the sunset of his (Baron) fortune, to be harmonised and assimilated with the noble features of his (Baron) character, so as to add peculiarity without exciting ridicule. His (Baron) mind occupied with such projects of future happiness, Edward sought Little Veolan, the habitation of Mr. Duncan Macwheeble.

CHAPTER XXXVII

Now is Cupid a child of conscience--he (Cupid) makes restitution.--SHAKSPEARE

Mr. Duncan MacWheeble, no longer Commissary or Bailie, though still enjoying the empty name of the latter dignity, had escaped proscription by an early secession from the insurgent party and by his (MacWheeble) insignificance.

Edward found him (Edward) in his (Edward) office, immersed among papers and accounts. Before him (Edward) was a large bicker of oatmeal porridge, and at the side thereof a horn spoon and a bottle of two-penny. Eagerly running his (Edward) eye over a voluminous law-paper, he (Edward) from time to time shovelled an immense spoonful of these nutritive viands into his (Edward) capacious mouth. A pot-bellied Dutch bottle of brandy which stood by intimated either that this honest limb of the law had taken his (Edward) morning already, or that he (Edward) meant to season his (Edward) porridge with such digestive; or perhaps both circumstances might reasonably be inferred. His (Edward) night-cap and morning-gown, had whilome been of tartan, but, equally cautious and frugal, the honest Bailie had got them dyed black, lest their original ill-omened colour might remind his (Bailie) visitors of his (Bailie) unlucky excursion to Derby. To sum up the picture, his (Bailie) face was daubed with snuff up to the eyes, and his (Bailie) fingers with ink up to the knuckles. He (Bailie) looked dubiously at Waverley as he (Bailie) approached the little green rail which fenced his (Bailie) desk and stool from the approach of the vulgar. Nothing could give the Bailie more annoyance than the idea of his (Bailie) acquaintance being claimed by any of the unfortunate gentlemen who were now so much more likely to need assistance than to afford profit. But this was the rich young Englishman; who knew what might be his (Englishman) situation? He (Englishman) was the Baron's friend too; what was to be done?

While these reflections gave an air of absurd perplexity to the poor man's visage, Waverley, reflecting on the communication he (man) was about to make to him (man), of a nature so ridiculously contrasted with the appearance of the individual, could not help bursting out a-laughing, as he (individual) checked the propensity to exclaim with Syphax--

Cato's a proper person to intrust A love-tale with.

As Mr. Macwheeble had no idea of any person laughing heartily who was either encircled by peril or oppressed by poverty, the hilarity of Edward's countenance greatly relieved the embarrassment of his (Edward) own, and, giving him (Edward) a tolerably hearty welcome to Little Veolan, he (Edward) asked what he (Edward) would choose for breakfast. His (Edward) visitor had, in the first place, something for his (Edward) private ear, and begged leave to bolt the door. Duncan by no means liked this precaution, which savoured of danger to be apprehended; but he (Duncan) could not now draw back.

Convinced he (Duncan) might trust this man, as he (Duncan) could make it his (Duncan) interest to be faithful, Edward communicated his (Edward) present situation and future schemes to Macwheeble. The wily agent listened with apprehension when he (agent) found Waverley was still in a state of proscription; was somewhat comforted by learning that he (Waverley) had a passport; rubbed his (Waverley) hands with glee when he (Waverley) mentioned the amount of his (Waverley) present fortune; opened huge eyes when he (Waverley) heard the brilliancy of his (Waverley) future expectations; but when he (Waverley) expressed his (Waverley) intention to share them with Miss Rose Bradwardine, ecstasy had almost deprived the honest man of his (man) senses. The Bailie started from his (Bailie) three-footed stool like the Pythoness from her (Bailie) tripod; flung his (Bailie) best wig out of the window, because the block on which it was placed stood in the way of his (Bailie) career; chucked his (Bailie) cap to the ceiling, caught it as it fell; whistled `Tullochgorum'; danced a Highland fling with inimitable grace and agility, and then threw himself exhausted into a chair, exclaiming, `Lady Wauverley! ten thousand a year the least penny! Lord preserve my poor understanding!'

`Amen with all my heart,' said Waverley; `but now, Mr. Macwheeble, let us proceed to business.' This word had somewhat a sedative effect, but the Bailie's head, as he (Bailie) expressed himself, was still `in the bees.' He (Bailie) mended his (Bailie) pen, however, marked half a dozen sheets of paper with an ample marginal fold, whipped down Dallas of St. Martin's `Styles' from a shelf, where that venerable work roosted with Stair's `Institutions,' Dirleton's `Doubts,' Balfour's `Practiques,' and a parcel of old account-books, opened the volume at the article Contract of Marriage, and prepared to make what he (Balfour) called a'sma' minute to prevent parties frae resiling.'

With some difficulty Waverley made him (Waverley) comprehend that he (Waverley) was going a little too fast. He (Waverley) explained to him (Waverley) that he (Waverley) should want his (Waverley) assistance, in the first place, to make his (Waverley) residence safe for the time, by writing to the officer at Tully-Veolan that Mr. Stanley, an English gentleman nearly related to Colonel Talbot, was upon a visit of business at Mr. Macwheeble's, and, knowing the state of the country, had sent his (Macwheeble) passport for Captain Foster's inspection. This produced a polite answer from the officer, with an invitation to Mr. Stanley to dine with him (Stanley), which was declined -LRB-as may easily be supposed-RRB- under pretence of business.

Waverley's next request was, that Mr. Macwheeble would despatch a man and horse to--, the post-town at which Colonel Talbot was to address him (Talbot), with directions to wait there until the post should bring a letter for Mr. Stanley, and then to forward it to Little Veolan with all speed. In a moment the Bailie was in search of his (Bailie) apprentice -LRB-or servitor, as he (Bailie) was called Sixty Years Since-RRB-, Jock Scriever, and in not much greater space of time Jock was on the back of the white pony. `Tak care ye guide him (Tak) weel, sir, for he (Tak)'s aye been short in the wind since--ahem--Lord be gude to me! -LRB-in a low voice-RRB-, I was gaun to come out wi'--since I rode whip and spur to fetch the Chevalier to redd Mr. Wauverley and Vich Ian Vohr; and an uncanny coup I gat for my pains. Lord forgie your honour! I might hae broken my neck; but troth it was in a venture, mae ways nor ane; but this maks amends for a'. Lady Wauverley! ten thousand a year! Lord be gude unto me!'

`But you forget, Mr. Macwheeble, we want the Baron's consent--the lady's--'

`Never fear, I'se be caution for them; I'se gie you my personal warrandice. Ten thousand a year! it dings Balmawhapple out and out--a year's rent's worth a' Balmawhapple, fee and life-rent! Lord make us thankful!'

To turn the current of his (Lord) feelings, Edward inquired if he (Edward) had heard anything lately of the Chieftain of Glennaquoich.

`Not one word,' answered Macwheeble, `but that he (Macwheeble) was still in Carlisle Castle, and was soon to be panelled for his (Macwheeble) life. I dinna wish the young gentleman ill,' he (Macwheeble) said, `but I hope that they that hae got him (Macwheeble) will keep him (Macwheeble), and no let him (Macwheeble) back to this Hieland border to plague us wi' black-mail and a' manner o' violent, wrongous, and masterfu' oppression and spoliation, both by himself and others of his (Macwheeble) causing, sending, and hounding out; and he (Macwheeble) couldna tak care o' the siller when he (Macwheeble) had gotten it neither, but flung it a' into yon idle quean's lap at Edinburgh; but light come light gane. For my part, I never wish to see a kilt in the country again, nor a red-coat, nor a gun, for that matter, unless it were to shoot a paitrick; they're a' tarr'd wi' ae stick. And when they have done ye wrang, even when ye hae gotten decreet of spuilzie, oppression, and violent profits against them, what better are ye? They hae na a plack to pay ye; ye need never extract it.'

With such discourse, and the intervening topics of business, the time passed until dinner, Macwheeble meanwhile promising to devise some mode of introducing Edward at the Duchran, where Rose at present resided, without risk of danger or suspicion; which seemed no very easy task, since the laird was a very zealous friend to government. The poultry-yard had been laid under requisition, and cockyleeky and Scotch collops soon reeked in the Bailie's little parlour. The landlord's cork-screw was just introduced into the muzzle of a pint bottle of claret -LRB-cribbed possibly from the cellars of Tully-Veolan-RRB-, when the sight of the grey pony passing the window at full trot induced the Bailie, but with due precaution, to place it aside for the moment. Enter Jock Scriever with a packet for Mr. Stanley; it is Colonel Talbot's seal, and Edward's ringers tremble as he (Edward) undoes it. Two official papers, folded, signed, and sealed in all formality, drop out. They were hastily picked up by the Bailie, who had a natural respect for everything resembling a deed, and, glancing slily on their titles, his (Bailie) eyes, or rather spectacles, are greeted with `Protection by his (Bailie) Royal Highness to the person of Cosmo Comyne Bradwardine, Esq., of that ilk, commonly called Baron of Bradwardine, forfeited for his (Baron) accession to the late rebellion.' The other proves to be a protection of the same tenor in favour of Edward Waverley, Esq.. Colonel Talbot's letter was in these words:--

`My DEAR EDWARD,

`I am just arrived here, and yet I have finished my business; it has cost me some trouble though, as you shall hear. I waited upon his (Talbot) Royal Highness immediately on my arrival, and found him (Talbot) in no very good humour for my purpose. Three or four Scotch gentlemen were just leaving his (Talbot) levee. After he (Talbot) had expressed himself to me very courteously;

``Would you think it,'' (me)
he (Talbot) said,
``Talbot, here have been half a dozen of the most respectable gentlemen and best friends to government north of the Forth, Major Melville of Cairnvreckan, Rubrick of Duchran, and others, who have fairly wrung from me, by their downright importunity, a present protection and the promise of a future pardon for that stubborn old rebel whom they call Baron of Bradwardine. (he)
This was no favourable moment for opening my business; however, I said I was rejoiced to learn that his (Talbot) Royal Highness was in the course of granting such requests, as it emboldened me to present one of the like nature in my own name. He (Highness) was very angry, but I persisted; I mentioned the uniform support of our three votes in, the house, touched modestly on services abroad, though valuable only in his (Highness) Royal Highness's having been pleased kindly to accept them, and founded pretty strongly on his (Highness) own expressions of friendship and good-will. He (Highness) was embarrassed, but obstinate. I hinted the policy of detaching, on all future occasions, the heir of such a fortune as your uncle's from the machinations of the disaffected. He (Highness) was not prepared for this; he (Highness) told me to take up my commission, said some handsome things of my services, and granted my request. Thus you see my prince can be as generous as yours. He (Melville) will of course repair to the Duchran without loss of time, there to ride quarantine for a few weeks. As for you, I give you leave to escort him (Melville) thither, and to stay a week there, as I understand a certain fair lady is in that quarter. And I have the pleasure to tell you that whatever progress you can make in her (lady) good graces will be highly agreeable to Sir Everard and Mrs. Rachel, who will never believe your views and prospects settled, and the three ermines passant in actual safety, until you present them with a Mrs. Edward Waverley. Therefore make good use of your time, for, when your week is expired, it will be necessary that you go to London to plead your pardon in the law courts.

`Ever, dear Waverley, yours most truly, `PHILIP TALBOT.'

CHAPTER XXXVIII

Happy's the wooing That's not long a doing.

When the first rapturous sensation occasioned by these excellent tidings had somewhat subsided, Edward proposed instantly to go down to the glen to acquaint the Baron with their import. But the cautious Bailie justly observed that, if the Baron were to appear instantly in public, the tenantry and villagers might become riotous in expressing their joy, and give offence to `the powers that be,' a sort of persons for whom the Bailie always had unlimited respect. He (gentleman) threw for life or death, a coronet or a coffin; and he (gentleman) cannot now be permitted, with justice to the country, to draw stakes because the dice have gone against him (gentleman).'

Such was the reasoning of those times, held even by brave and humane men towards a vanquished enemy. Let us devoutly hope that, in this respect at least, we shall never see the scenes or hold the sentiments that were general in Britain Sixty Years Since.

CHAPTER XXXIX

To morrow? O that's sudden!--Spare him (gentleman), spare him (gentleman)'--SHAKSPEARE

Edward, attended by his (Edward) former servant Alick Polwarth, who had reentered his (Edward) service at Edinburgh, reached Carlisle while the commission of Oyer and Terminer on his (Edward) unfortunate associates was yet sitting. He (Edward) had pushed forward in haste, not, alas! with the most distant hope of saving Fergus, but to see him (Fergus) for the last time. I ought to have mentioned that he (Fergus) had furnished funds for the defence of the prisoners in the most liberal manner, as soon as he (Fergus) heard that the day of trial was fixed. A solicitor and the first counsel accordingly attended; but it was upon the same footing on which the first physicians are usually summoned to the bedside of some dying man of rank--the doctors to take the advantage of some incalculable chance of an exertion of nature, the lawyers to avail themselves of the barely possible occurrence of some legal flaw. What have you to say for yourselves why the Court should not pronounce judgment against you, that you die according to law?'

Yesterday and the day before you have condemned loyal and honourable blood to be poured forth like water. Spare not mine. Were that of all my ancestors in my veins, I would have perilled it in this quarrel.' He (God) resumed his (God) seat and refused again to rise.

Notwithstanding the solemnity of the occasion, a sort of laugh was heard in the court at the extraordinary nature of the proposal. The Judge checked this indecency, and Evan, looking sternly around, when the murmur abated, `If the Saxon gentlemen are laughing,' he (Evan) said, `because a poor man, such as me, thinks my life, or the life of six of my degree, is worth that of Vich Ian Vohr, it's like enough they may be very right; but if they laugh because they think I would not keep my word and come back to redeem him (Vohr), I can tell them they ken neither the heart of a Hielandman nor the honour of a gentleman.'

There was no farther inclination to laugh among the audience, and a dead silence ensued.

The Judge then pronounced upon both prisoners the sentence of the law of high treason, with all its horrible accompaniments. The execution was appointed for the ensuing day. `For you, Fergus Mac-Ivor,' continued the Judge, `I can hold out no hope of mercy. You must prepare against to-morrow for your last sufferings here, and your great audit hereafter.'

`I desire nothing else, my lord,' answered Fergus, in the same manly and firm tone.

`Vain indeed!' echoed Waverley.

`Or even of the future, my good friend,' said Flora, `so far as earthly events are concerned; for how often have I pictured to myself the strong possibility of this horrid issue, and tasked myself to consider how I could support my part; and yet how far has all my anticipation fallen short of the unimaginable bitterness of this hour!'

`Dear Flora, if your strength of mind--'

`Ay, there it is,' she (Flora) answered, somewhat wildly; `there is, Mr. Waverley, there is a busy devil at my heart that whispers--but it were madness to listen to it--that the strength of mind on which Flora prided herself has murdered her (Flora) brother!'

`Good God! how can you give utterance to a thought so shocking?'

`Ay, is it not so? but yet it haunts me like a phantom; I know it is unsubstantial and vain; but it will be present; will intrude its horrors on my mind; will whisper that my brother, as volatile as ardent, would have divided his (brother) energies amid a hundred objects. It was I who taught him (brother) to concentrate them and to gage all on this dreadful and desperate cast. Oh that I could recollect that I had but once said to him (brother),

``He (Rubrick) that striketh with the sword shall die by the sword'' (him)
; that I had but once said,
``Remain at home; reserve yourself, your vassals, your life, for enterprises within the reach of man.'' (I)
But O, Mr. Waverley, I spurred his (Waverley) fiery temper, and half of his (Waverley) ruin at least lies with his (Waverley) sister!'

The horrid idea which she (sister) had intimated, Edward endeavoured to combat by every incoherent argument that occurred to him (Edward). He (Edward) recalled to her (sister) the principles on which both thought it their duty to act, and in which they had been educated.

`Do not think I have forgotten them,' she (sister) said, looking up with eager quickness; `I do not regret his (Edward) attempt because it was wrong!--O no! on that point I am armed--but because it was impossible it could end otherwise than thus.'

`Yet it did not always seem so desperate and hazardous as it was; and it would have been chosen by the bold spirit of Fergus whether you had approved it or no; your counsels only served to give unity and consistence to his (Fergus) conduct; to dignify, but not to precipitate, his (Fergus) resolution.' Flora had soon ceased to listen to Edward, and was again intent upon her (Flora) needlework.

`Do you remember,' she (Flora) said, looking up with a ghastly smile, `you once found me making Fergus's bride-favours, and now I am sewing his (Fergus) bridal garment. Our friends here,' she (Flora) continued, with suppressed emotion, `are to give hallowed earth in their chapel to the bloody relics of the last Vich Ian Vohr. When he (Edward) was recalled, after the space of nearly half an hour, he (Edward) found that, by a strong effort, Miss Mac-Ivor had greatly composed herself. She (princess) put into his (Rose) hands a case containing the chain of diamonds with which she (princess) used to decorate her (princess) hair. `To me it is in future useless. The kindness of my friends has secured me a retreat in the convent of the Scottish Benedictine nuns in Paris. May you be as happy with Rose as your amiable dispositions deserve; and think sometimes on the friends you have lost. Do not attempt to see me again; it would be mistaken kindness.'

She (sister) gave him (Rose) her (sister) hand, on which Edward shed a torrent of tears, and with a faltering step withdrew from the apartment, and returned to the town of Carlisle. CHAPTER XL

A darker departure is near, The death drum is muffled, and sable the bier--CAMPBELL

After a sleepless night, the first dawn of morning found Waverley on the esplanade in front of the old Gothic gate of Carlisle Castle. He (Sheriff) produced his (Sheriff) order to the sergeant of the guard and was admitted.

The place of Fergus's confinement was a gloomy and vaulted apartment in the central part of the Castle; a huge old tower, supposed to be of great antiquity, and surrounded by outworks, seemingly of Henry VIII's time, or somewhat later. The grating of the large old-fashioned bars and bolts, withdrawn for the purpose of admitting Edward, was answered by the clash of chains, as the unfortunate Chieftain, strongly and heavily fettered, shuffled along the stone floor of his (Chieftain) prison to fling himself into his (Chieftain) friend's arms.

`My dear Edward,' he (Edward) said, in a firm and even cheerful voice, `this is truly kind. I heard of your approaching happiness with the highest pleasure. And how does Rose? and how is our old whimsical friend the Baron? Well, I trust, since I see you at freedom. `He (Prince) has, and is in safety.'

Waverley communicated that remarkable history, so far as it had then transpired, to which Fergus listened with deep interest. They had suffered less than other tribes who had been engaged in the affair; for, having in a great measure dispersed and returned home after the captivity of their Chieftain, according to the universal custom of the Highlanders, they were not in arms when the insurrection was finally suppressed, and consequently were treated with less rigour. This Fergus heard with great satisfaction.

`You are rich,' he (Fergus) said, `Waverley, and you are generous. When you hear of these poor Mac-Ivors being distressed about their miserable possessions by some harsh overseer or agent of government, remember you have worn their tartan and are an adopted son of their race, The Baron, who knows our manners and lives near our country, will apprise you of the time and means to be their protector. Will you promise this to the last Vich Ian Vohr?'

Edward, as may well be believed, pledged his (Edward) word; which he (Edward) afterwards so amply redeemed that his (Edward) memory still lives in these glens by the name of the Friend of the Sons of Ivor.

The tears which his (Evan) own fate could not draw forth fell fast for that of his (Evan) foster-brother.

You cannot be to them Vich Ian Vohr; and these three magic words,' said he (Vohr), half smiling, `are the only Open Sesame to their feelings and sympathies, and poor Evan must attend his (Evan) foster-brother in death, as he (Evan) has done through his (Evan) whole life.'

`You see the compliment they pay to our Highland strength and courage; we have lain chained here like wild beasts, till our legs are cramped into palsy, and when they free us they send six soldiers with loaded muskets to prevent our taking the castle by storm!'

Edward afterwards learned that these severe precautions had been taken in consequence of a desperate attempt of the prisoners to escape, in which they had very nearly succeeded.

Shortly afterwards the drums of the garrison beat to arms. `This is the last turn-out,' said Fergus, `that I shall hear and obey. And now, my dear, dear Edward, ere we part let us speak of Flora--a subject which awakes the tenderest feeling that yet thrills within me.'

`We part not here!' said Waverley.

`O yes, we do; you must come no farther. Not that I fear what is to follow for myself,' he (Waverley) said proudly. `Nature has her (Flora) tortures as well as art, and how happy should we think the man who escapes from the throes of a mortal and painful disorder in the space of a short half hour? Moritur, et moriens dukes reminiscitur Argos.'

A bustle, and the sound of wheels and horses' feet, was now heard in the court-yard of the Castle. `As I have told you why you must not follow me, and these sounds admonish me that my time flies fast, tell me how you found poor Flora.'

CHAPTER XLI

DULCE DOMUM

The impression of horror with which Waverley left Carlisle softened by degrees into melancholy, a gradation which was accelerated by the painful yet soothing task of writing to Rose; and, while he (Rose) could not suppress his (Rose) own feelings of the calamity, he (Rose) endeavoured to place it in a light which might grieve her (it) without shocking her (it) imagination. The picture which he (Rose) drew for her (it) benefit he (Rose) gradually familiarised to his (Rose) own mind, and his (Rose) next letters were more cheerful, and referred to the prospects of peace and happiness which lay before them. Yet, though his (Rose) first horrible sensations had sunk into melancholy, Edward had reached his (Edward) native country before he (Edward) could, as usual on former occasions, look round for enjoyment upon the face of nature.

He (Edward) then, for the first time since leaving Edinburgh, began to experience that pleasure which almost all feel who return to a verdant, populous, and highly cultivated country from scenes of waste desolation or of solitary and melancholy grandeur. But how were those feelings enhanced when he (Edward) entered on the domain so long possessed by his (Edward) forefathers; recognised the old oaks of Waverley-Chace; thought with what delight he (Edward) should introduce Rose to all his (Edward) favourite haunts; beheld at length the towers of the venerable hall arise above the woods which embowered it, and finally threw himself into the arms of the venerable relations to whom he (Edward) owed so much duty and affection!

The happiness of their meeting was not tarnished by a single word of reproach. On the contrary, whatever pain Sir Everard and Mrs. Rachel had felt during Waverley's perilous engagement with the young Chevalier, it assorted too well with the principles in which they had been brought up to incur reprobation, or even censure.
