NOTE 35

The name of Andrea de Ferrara is inscribed on all the Scottish broadswords which are accounted of peculiar excellence. Who this artist was, what were his (artist) fortunes, and when he (artist) flourished, have hitherto defied the research of antiquaries; only it is in general believed that Andrea de Ferrara was a Spanish or Italian artificer, brought over by James IV or V to instruct the Scots in the manufacture of sword blades. Most barbarous nations excel in the fabrication of arms; and the Scots had attained great proficiency in forging swords so early as the field of Pinkie; at which period the historian Patten describes them as `all notably broad and thin, universally made to slice, and of such exceeding good temper that, as I never saw any so good, so I think it hard to devise better.'--Account of Somerset's Expedition.

It may be observed that the best and most genuine Andrea Ferraras have a crown marked on the blade.

NOTE 36

The incident here said to have happened to Flora Mac-Ivor actually befell Miss Nairne, a lady with whom the author had the pleasure of being acquainted. As the Highland army rushed into Edinburgh, Miss Nairne, like other ladies who approved of their cause, stood waving her (Nairne) handkerchief from a balcony, when a ball from a Highlander's musket, which was discharged by accident, grazed her (Nairne) forehead. `Thank God,' said she (Nairne), the instant she (Nairne) recovered, `that the accident happened to me, whose principles are known. Had it befallen a Whig, they would have said it was done on purpose.'

NOTE 37, p. 185

The Author of Waverley has been charged with painting the young Adventurer in colours more amiable than his (Adventurer) character deserved. But having known many individuals who were near his (Adventurer) person, he (Adventurer) has been described according to the light in which those eye-witnesses saw his (Adventurer) temper and qualifications. Something must be allowed, no doubt, to the natural exaggerations of those who remembered him (Adventurer) as the bold and adventurous Prince in whose cause they had braved death and ruin; but is their evidence to give place entirely to that of a single malcontent?

I have already noticed the imputations thrown by the Chevalier Johnstone on the Prince's courage. But some part at least of that gentleman's tale is purely romantic. It would not, for instance, be supposed that at the time he (gentleman) is favouring us with the highly wrought account of his (gentleman) amour with the adorable Peggie, the Chevalier Johnstone was a married man, whose grandchild is now alive; or that the whole circumstantial story concerning the outrageous vengeance taken by Gordon of Abbachie on a Presbyterian clergyman is entirely apocryphal. At the same time it may be admitted that the Prince, like others of his (Prince) family, did not esteem the services done him (Prince) by his (Prince) adherents so highly as he (Prince) ought. Educated in high ideas of his (Prince) hereditary right, he (Prince) has been supposed to have held every exertion and sacrifice made in his (Prince) cause as too much the duty of the person making it to merit extravagant gratitude on his (Prince) part. Dr. King's evidence -LRB-which his (Prince) leaving the Jacobite interest renders somewhat doubtful-RRB- goes to strengthen this opinion.

The ingenious editor of Johnstone's Memoirs has quoted a story said to be told by Helvetius, stating that Prince Charles Edward, far from voluntarily embarking on his (Edward) daring expedition, was, literally bound hand and foot, and to which he (Edward) seems disposed to yield credit. Now, it being a fact as well known as any in his (Edward) history, and, so far as I know, entirely undisputed, that the Prince's personal entreaties and urgency positively forced Boisdale and Lochiel into insurrection, when they were earnestly desirous that he (Prince) would put off his (Prince) attempt until he (Prince) could obtain a sufficient force from France, it will be very difficult to reconcile his (Prince) alleged reluctance to undertake the expedition with his (Prince) desperately insisting upon carrying the rising into effect against the advice and entreaty of his (Prince) most powerful and most sage partizans. Surely a man who had been carried bound on board the vessel which brought him (man) to so desperate an enterprise would have taken the opportunity afforded by the reluctance of his (man) partizans to return to France in safety.

It is averred in Johnstone's Memoirs that Charles Edward left the field of Culloden without doing the utmost to dispute the victory; and, to give the evidence on both sides, there is in existence the more trustworthy testimony of Lord Elcho, who states that he (Elcho) himself earnestly exhorted the Prince to charge at the head of the left wing, which was entire, and retrieve the day or die with honour. And on his (Prince) counsel being declined, Lord Elcho took leave of him (Elcho) with a bitter execration, swearing he (Elcho) would never look on his (Elcho) face again, and kept his (Elcho) word.

On the other hand, it seems to have been the opinion of almost all the other officers that the day was irretrievably lost, one wing of the Highlanders being entirely routed, the rest of the army outnumbered, outflanked, and in a condition totally hopeless. In this situation of things the Irish officers who surrounded Charles's person interfered to force him (Charles) off the field. A cornet who was close to the Prince left a strong attestation that he (Prince) had seen Sir Thomas Sheridan seize the bridle of his (Sheridan) horse and turn him (Sheridan) round. There is some discrepancy of evidence; but the opinion of Lord Elcho, a man of fiery temper and desperate at the ruin which he (Elcho) beheld impending, cannot fairly be taken in prejudice of a character for courage which is intimated by the nature of the enterprise itself, by the Prince's eagerness to fight on all occasions, by his (Prince) determination to advance from Derby to London, and by the presence of mind which he (Prince) manifested during the romantic perils of his (Prince) escape. The author is far from claiming for this unfortunate person the praise due to splendid talents; but he (Prince) continues to be of opinion that at the period of his (Prince) enterprise he (Prince) had a mind capable of facing danger and aspiring to fame.

That Charles Edward had the advantages of a graceful presence, courtesy, and an address and manner becoming his (Edward) station, the author never heard disputed by any who approached his (Edward) person, nor does he (Edward) conceive that these qualities are overcharged in the present attempt to sketch his (Edward) portrait.

The following extracts corroborative of the general opinion respecting the Prince's amiable disposition are taken from a manuscript account of his (Prince) romantic expedition, by James Maxwell of Kirkconnell, of which I possess a copy, by the friendship of J. Menzies, Esq., of Pitfoddells. The author, though partial to the Prince, whom he (Prince) faithfully followed, seems to have been a fair and candid man, and well acquainted with the intrigues among the adventurer's council:--

`Everybody was mightily taken with the Prince's figure and personal behaviour. There was but one voice about them. Those whom interest or prejudice made a runaway to his (Prince) cause could not help acknowledging that they wished him (Prince) well in all other respects, and could hardly blame him (Prince) for his (Prince) present undertaking. Sundry things had concurred to raise his (Prince) character to the highest pitch, besides the greatness of the enterprise and the conduct that had hitherto appeared in the execution of it.

`There were several instances of good nature and humanity that had made a great impression on people's minds. I shall confine myself to two or three.

`Immediately after the battle, as the Prince was riding along the ground that Cope's army had occupied a few minutes before, one of the officers came up to congratulate him (Prince), and said, pointing to the killed,

``Sir, there are your enemies at your feet.'' (him)
The Prince, far from exulting, expressed a great deal of compassion for his (Prince) father's deluded subjects, whom he (Prince) declared he (Prince) was heartily sorry to see in that posture.

`Next day, while the Prince was at Pinkie House, a citizen of Edinburgh came to make some representation to Secretary Murray about the tents that city was ordered to furnish against a certain day. Murray happened to be out of the way, which the Prince hearing of called to have the gentleman brought to him (Prince), saying, he (Prince) would rather despatch the business, whatever it was, himself than have the gentleman wait, which he (gentleman) did, by granting everything that was asked. So much affability in a young prince flushed with victory drew encomiums even from his (prince) enemies.

`But what gave the people the highest idea of him (prince) was the negative he (prince) gave to a thing that very nearly concerned his (prince) interest, and upon which the success of his (prince) enterprise perhaps depended. It was proposed to send one of the prisoners to London to demand of that court a cartel for the exchange of prisoners taken, and to be taken, during this war, and to intimate that a refusal would be looked upon as a resolution on their part to give no quarter. It was visible a cartel would be of great advantage to the Prince's affairs; his (Prince) friends would be more ready to declare for him (Prince) if they had nothing to fear but the chance of war in the field; and if the court of London refused to settle a cartel, the Prince was authorised to treat his (Prince) prisoners in the same manner the Elector of Hanover was determined to treat such of the Prince's friends as might fall into his (Prince) hands; it was urged that a few examples would compel the court of London to comply. It was to be presumed that the officers of the English army would make a point of it. They had never engaged in the service but upon such terms as are in use among all civilised nations, and it could be no stain upon their honour to lay down their commissions if these terms were not observed, and that owing to the obstinacy of their own Prince. Though this scheme was plausible, and represented as very important, the Prince could never be brought into it, it was below him (Prince), he (Prince) said, to make empty threats, and he (Prince) would never put such as those into execution; he (Prince) would never in cold blood take away lives which he (Prince) had saved in heat of action at the peril of his (Prince) own. These were not the only proofs of good nature the Prince gave about this time. Every day produced something new of this kind. These things softened the rigour of a military government which was only imputed to the necessity of his (Prince) affairs, and which he (Prince) endeavoured to make as gentle and easy as possible.'

It has been said that the Prince sometimes exacted more state and ceremonial than seemed to suit his (Prince) condition; but, on the other hand, some strictness of etiquette was altogether indispensable where he (Prince) must otherwise have been exposed to general intrusion. He (Prince) could also endure, with a good grace, the retorts which his (Prince) affectation of ceremony sometimes exposed him (Prince) to. It is said, for example, that Grant of Glenmoriston having made a hasty march to join Charles, at the head of his (Charles) clan, rushed into the Prince's presence at Holyrood with unceremonious haste, without having attended to the duties of the toilet. The Prince received him (Prince) kindly, but not without a hint that a previous interview with the barber might not have been wholly unnecessary. `It is not beardless boys,' answered the displeased Chief, `who are to do your Royal Highness's turn.' The Chevalier took the rebuke in good part.

On the whole, if Prince Charles had concluded his (Charles) life soon after his (Charles) miraculous escape, his (Charles) character in history must have stood very high. As it was, his (Charles) station is amongst those a certain brilliant portion of whose life forms a remarkable contrast to all which precedes and all which follows it.

NOTE 38

The following account of the skirmish at Clifton is extracted from the manuscript Memoirs of Evan Macpherson of Cluny, Chief of the clan Macpherson, who had the merit of supporting the principal brunt of that spirited affair. The Memoirs appear to have been composed about 1755, only ten years after the action had taken place. They were written in France, where that gallant chief resided in exile, which accounts for some Gallicisms which occur in the narrative.

`In the Prince's return from Derby back towards Scotland, my Lord George Murray, Lieutenant-General, cheerfully charg'd himself with the command of the rear, a post which, altho' honourable, was attended with great danger, many difficulties, and no small fatigue; for the Prince, being apprehensive that his (Prince) retreat to Scotland might be cut off by Marischall Wade, who lay to the northward of him (Wade) with an armie much superior to what H.R.H. had, while the Duke of Comberland with his (Wade) whole cavalrie followed hard in the rear, was obliged to hasten his (Wade) marches. It was not, therefore, possible for the artilirie to march so fast as the Prince's army, in the depth of winter, extremely bad weather, and the worst roads in England; so Lord George Murray was obliged often to continue his (Murray) marches long after it was dark almost every night, while at the same time he (Murray) had frequent alarms and disturbances from the Duke of Comberland's advanc'd parties.

`Towards the evening of the twentie-eight December 1745 the Prince entered the town of Penrith, in the Province of Comberland. But as Lord George Murray could not bring up the artilirie so fast as he (Murray) wou'd have wish'd, he (Murray) was oblig'd to pass the night six miles short of that town, together with the regiment of MacDonel of Glengarrie, which that day happened to have the arrear guard. The Prince, in order to refresh his (Prince) armie, and to give My Lord George and the artilirie time to come up, resolved to sejour the 29th at Penrith; so ordered his (George) little army to appear in the morning under arms, in order to be reviewed, and to know in what manner the numbers stood from his (George) haveing entered England. It did not at that time amount to 5000 foot in all, with about 400 cavalrie, compos'd of the noblesse who serv'd as volunteers, part of whom form'd a first troop of guards for the Prince, under the command of My Lord Elchoe, now Comte de Weems, who, being proscribed, is presently in France. Another part formed a second troup of guards under the command of My Lord Balmirino, who was beheaded at the Tower of London. A third part serv'd under My Lord le Comte de Kilmarnock, who was likewise beheaded at the Tower. A fourth part serv'd under My Lord Pitsligow, who is also proscribed; which cavalrie, tho' very few in numbers, being all noblesse, were very brave, and of infinite advantage to the foot, not only in the day of battle, but in serving as advanced guards on the several marches, and in patroling dureing the night on the different roads which led towards the towns where the army happened to quarter.

`While this small army was out in a body on the 20th December, upon a riseing ground to the northward of Penrith, passing review, Mons. de Cluny, with his (Cluny) tribe, was ordered to the Bridge of Clifton, about a mile to southward of Penrith, after having pass'd in review before Mons. Pattullo, who was charged with the inspection of the troops, and was likeways Quarter-Master-General of the army, and is now in France. They remained under arms at the bridge, waiting the arrival of My Lord George Murray with the artilirie, whom Mons. de Cluny had orders to cover in passing the bridge. They arrived about sunset closly pursued by the Duke of Comberland with the whole body of his (Murray) cavalrie, reckoned upwards of 3000 strong, about a thousand of whom, as near as might be computed, dismounted, in order to cut off the passage of the artilirie towards the bridge, while the Duke and the others remained on horseback in order to attack the rear.

`My Lord George Murray advanced, and although he (Murray) found Mons. de Cluny and his (Cluny) tribe in good spirits under arms, yet the circumstance appear'd extremely delicate. The numbers were vastly unequall, and the attack seem'd very dangerous; so My Lord George declin'd giving orders to such time as he (George) ask'd Mons. de Cluny's opinion.

``I will attack them with all my heart,'' (Mons)
says Mons. de Cluny,
``if you order me.'' (unknown)
``I do order it then,'' (George/Lord George Murray/Lord George)
answered My Lord George, and immediately went on himself along with Mons. de Cluny, and fought sword in hand on foot at the head of the single tribe of Macphersons. They in a moment made their way through a strong hedge of thorns, under the cover whereof the cavalrie had taken their station, in the struggle of passing which hedge My Lord George Murray, being dressed en montagnard, as all the army were, lost his (Murray) bonet and wig; so continued to fight bare-headed during the action. They at first made a brisk discharge of their firearms on the enemy, then attacked them with their sabres, and made a great slaughter a considerable time, which obliged Comberland and his (Murray) cavalrie to fly with precipitation and in great confusion; in so much that, if the Prince had been provided in a sufficient number of cavalrie to have taken advantage of the disorder, it is beyond question that the Duke of Comberland and the bulk of his (Prince) cavalrie had been taken prisoners.

`By this time it was so dark that it was not possible to view or number the slain who filled all the ditches which happened to be on the ground where they stood. But it was computed that, besides those who went off wounded, upwards of a hundred at least were left on the spot, among whom was Colonel Honywood, who commanded the dismounted cavalrie, whose sabre of considerable value Mons. de Cluny brought off and still preserves; and his (Colonel) tribe lykeways brought off many arms;--the Colonel was afterwards taken up, and, his (Colonel) wounds being dress'd, with great difficultie recovered. Mons. de Cluny lost only in the action twelve men, of whom some haveing been only wounded, fell afterwards into the hands of the enemy, and were sent as slaves to America, whence several of them returned, and one of them is now in France, a sergeant in the Regiment of Royal Scots. How soon the accounts of the enemies approach had reached the Prince, H.R.H. had immediately ordered Mi-Lord le Comte de Nairne, Brigadier, who, being proscribed, is now in France, with the three batalions of the Duke of Athol, the batalion of the Duke of Perth, and some other troups under his (Brigadier) command, in order to support Cluny, and to bring off the artilirie. But the action was entirely over before the Comte de Nairne, with his (Brigadier) command, cou'd reach nigh to the place. They therefore return'd all to Penrith, and the artilirie marched up in good order.

`Nor did the Duke of Comberland ever afterwards dare to come within a day's march of the Prince and his (Prince) army dureing the course of all that retreat, which was conducted with great prudence and safety when in some manner surrounded by enemies.'

NOTE 39

As the heathen deities contracted an indelible obligation if they swore by Styx, the Scottish Highlanders had usually some peculiar solemnity attached to an oath which they intended should be binding on them. Very frequently it consisted in laying their hand, as they swore, on their own drawn dirk; which dagger, becoming a party to the transaction, was invoked to punish any breach of faith. But by whatever ritual the oath was sanctioned, the party was extremely desirous to keep secret what the especial oath was which he (enemies) considered as irrevocable. This was a matter of great convenience, as he (enemies) felt no scruple in breaking his (enemies) asseveration when made in any other form than that which he (enemies) accounted as peculiarly solemn; and therefore readily granted any engagement which bound him (enemies) no longer than he (enemies) inclined. Whereas, if the oath which he (enemies) accounted inviolable was once publicly known, no party with whom he (enemies) might have occasion to contract would have rested satisfied with any other.

Louis XI of France practised the same sophistry, for he (Louis) also had a peculiar species of oath, the only one which he (Louis) was ever known to respect, and which, therefore, he (Louis) was very unwilling to pledge. The only engagement which that wily tyrant accounted binding upon him (tyrant) was an oath by the Holy Cross of Saint Lo dAngers, which contained a portion of the True Cross. If he (Saint) prevaricated after taking this oath Louis believed he (Louis) should die within the year. The Constable Saint Paul, being invited to a personal conference with Louis, refused to meet the king unless he (Louis) would agree to ensure him (Louis) safe conduct under sanction of this oath. But, says Comines, the king replied, he (king) would never again pledge that engagement to mortal man, though he (king) was willing to take any other oath which could be devised. The treaty broke oft, therefore, after much chaffering concerning the nature of the vow which Louis was to take. Such is the difference between the dictates of superstition and those of conscience.
